questions.text: One day after undergoing left carotid endarterectomy, a 63-year-old man has a severe headache. He describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. He has nausea. He had 80% stenosis in the left carotid artery and received heparin prior to the surgery. He has a history of two transient ischemic attacks, which occurred two and four months ago, respectively. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He drinks 1–2 beers on weekends. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows pupils that react sluggishly to light. There is a right facial droop. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the right. There is a left cervical surgical incision that shows no erythema or discharge. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, electrolytes, and glucose are within the reference range. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis is a risk factor for embolic (through carotid plaque emboli) and thrombotic (through carotid plaque thrombosis) ischemic stroke. Carotid stroke and intracerebral hemorrhage also share multiple risk factors. However, patients with early signs of ischemic stroke on noncontrast CT typically have hypodense parenchyma and loss of grey-white matter differentiation; this patient has a hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema, which indicates ICH.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A hypodense occipital infarct (green) in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery is accompanied by a loss of normal gray-white matter differentiation. The density of the lesion is greater than that of CSF. There is no mass effect or hemorrhage. Choroid plexus calcifications in the lateral ventricles are physiologic.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation, theoretically predisposing patients to bleeding such as intracerebral hemorrhage. However, aspirin therapy only minimally increases the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage, if at all.

C) INCORRECT:

The risk of intracerebral hemorrhage is directly correlated with the degree of anticoagulation (e.g., by heparin). However, anticoagulation is not the strongest risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage.

D) CORRECT:

Arterial hypertension is the single most important predisposing factor for atraumatic intracerebral hemorrhage. Chronic hypertension results in lipohyalinosis of the arterial walls, leading to microaneurysm formation and elevated risk of rupture. Acute hypertension then leads to rupture of the weakened vessels, which likely was the mechanism of rupture in this patient.

Management of intracerebral hemorrhage depends on the intracranial pressure (ICP) of the patient. If ICP is normal, blood pressure should be decreased to < 160 mm Hg through labetalol or nicardipine administration. If intracranial hypertension is suspected (as is likely in this patient, given his altered mental status and sluggishly reactive pupils), blood pressure should be lowered more cautiously, as cerebral perfusion must be maintained. Finally, if herniation is suspected (e.g., uncal herniation), emergency craniotomy is required.
Image Description:

Hemorrhage in the region of the left basal ganglia causing a midline shift to the right

The basal ganglia are supplied by the lenticulostriate arteries, which arise from the middle cerebral artery. Hemorrhage from a lenticulostriate artery (e.g., due to poorly controlled hypertension or rupture of a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm) leads to a basal ganglia hemorrhage.

E) INCORRECT:

Smoking does increase the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage in a dose-response relationship. The mechanism is likely multifactorial and includes both increased blood pressure and arterial wall damage associated with smoking. However, it is not the strongest risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage.
questions.hint: This patient has clinical features of a stroke (e.g., facial droop, right-sided hemiparesis, hyperreflexia, headache) and a CT scan of the head that shows intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH; hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema) in the left hemisphere.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gout. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He drinks 3 cans of beer daily. His current medications include aspirin, metformin, enalapril, simvastatin, and febuxostat. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference ranges. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is typically the first-line imaging modality for patients with symptomatic CAS (e.g., TIA, amaurosis fugax, ischemic stroke). Some guidelines also recommend ultrasonography of the neck to screen for CAS in asymptomatic patients with a carotid bruit and multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In patients with CAS, ultrasonography shows a focally-increased velocity of blood flow. Duplex ultrasonography is an inexpensive, noninvasive test with high specificity and sensitivity for the detection of CAS. It can also quantify the degree of stenosis.

Antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, blood pressure control, and lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation, weight control, regular exercise) are the mainstays of treatment in CAS. Carotid revascularization (typically with carotid endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease and severe stenosis (≥ 70%).

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to identify cardiogenic sources of emboli in patients with symptomatic ischemic neurological disease (e.g., TIA) without a clear intracranial or extracranial vascular etiology. However, this patient's physical exam revealed a carotid bruit that is likely secondary to CAS. Echocardiography would not be the next best step for evaluating CAS.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with CAS, anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are not used for stroke prevention. Instead, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) are used. Warfarin is used for stroke prevention only in patients with certain risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves).

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography and MR angiography are not first-line imaging modalities in the workup of CAS, but they can be used to confirm the diagnosis if the first-line modality shows findings consistent with the condition or yields inconclusive results (e.g., due to significant carotid artery calcification). Angiography also plays a role in preoperative risk stratification and intervention planning.

E) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography of the neck, which requires arterial catheterization, used to be the preferred test for evaluating CAS but it has been replaced by other modalities because it is an invasive and costly procedure that carries a ∼ 4% risk of iatrogenic neurological complications (e.g., stroke). Although it may have some utility in select patient groups (e.g., if the initial imaging modalities reveal discordant results or additional anatomic detail is needed), it would not be used as a first-line diagnostic test.
Image Description:

MR angiography (right carotid artery)

There is severe stenosis (hatched green overlay) of the proximal internal carotid artery.

1: superior thyroid artery; 2: lingual artery; 3: facial artery
questions.hint: This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of slurred speech and left facial droop for the past 30 minutes. During this period, she has also had numbness on the left side of her face. She has never had such an episode before. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her father died of lung cancer 1 week ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She drinks one glass of wine daily. Her current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. She is oriented to person, place, and time but speaks slowly with slurred speech. Her temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left side of the face. Examination shows full muscle strength. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. A finger-nose test and her gait are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a right-sided carotid bruit. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, glucose, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows no abnormalities. On the way back from the CT scan, her presenting symptoms resolve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Functional neurological symptom disorder is characterized by significant distress and/or psychosocial impairment caused by neurologic symptoms (e.g., paralysis, weakness, visual disturbances) that cannot be fully attributed to another condition. Stressful events (e.g., loss of a close relative) are a risk factor for this condition. Although functional neurological symptom disorder cannot be excluded entirely, this condition is a diagnosis of exclusion and another diagnosis is more likely in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A partial seizure is a surge of electrical activity that starts in one hemisphere of the brain (and is therefore focal). It may manifest with a variety of symptoms depending on which area of the cortex is affected. In this patient with cardiovascular risk factors and no history of focal epilepsy, a different diagnosis is more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Stroke workup is indicated in all patients presenting with new focal neurologic deficits (e.g., facial palsy). In addition, this patient has substantial risk factors for cardiovascular disease and therefore stroke. However, symptoms in this patient resolve spontaneously and there is no evidence of ischemia on CT imaging, which is diagnostic of a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Although Bell palsy is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis and may cause slurred speech, facial sensation would be unaffected and recovery would typically take a few weeks.

E) CORRECT:

Sudden onset of focal neurologic deficits (facial droop, numbness, and slurred speech) in a patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors as well as a carotid bruit is highly suggestive of cerebral ischemia (stroke). Because this patient's focal symptoms resolve spontaneously without intervention and there is no evidence of ischemia on neuroimaging, it is by definition a transient ischemic attack (TIA) rather than a stroke.

In patients with ongoing symptoms of stroke, an emergency noncontrast CT scan of the head is used to exclude intracranial hemorrhage. If there is no evidence of stroke on the emergency CT scan or in patients with resolving symptoms, a diffusion-weighted MRI can be used to detect signs of reversible ischemia and diagnose TIA. Besides neuroimaging, antiplatelet therapy should be initiated urgently because TIA is associated with a high risk of subsequent stroke.

F) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a demyelinating condition of the CNS that can be diagnosed according to McDonald's criteria. This diagnosis requires clinical symptoms and CNS lesions to be distributed over space and time, meaning there is a history of otherwise unexplained neurologic symptoms in the past and CNS lesions are seen on MRI in different locations and at differing stages (new and old). A suspected first episode of neurologic deficits in the context of MS (e.g., opticus neuritis) is called a clinically isolated syndrome (CIS), which may partially or fully resolve (like relapsing-remitting MS). However, a sudden onset of symptoms within minutes and resolution of symptoms within one hour are neither consistent with an episode of CIS nor MS.
questions.hint: This patient with risk factors for cardiovascular disease (obesity, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, smoking history) has sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits (facial palsy) that resolve without treatment.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of headache, blurred vision, and numbness of the right leg for the past 2 hours. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril and metformin. He is oriented only to person. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to fine touch and position is decreased over the right lower extremity. The confrontation test shows loss of the nasal field in the left eye and the temporal field in the right eye with macular sparing. He is unable to read phrases shown to him but can write them when they are dictated to him. He has short-term memory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Infarct of the right middle cerebral artery
Infarct of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Infarct of the right posterior cerebral artery
Infarct of the right anterior cerebral artery
Infarct of the left middle cerebral artery
Infarct of the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery
Infarct of the left anterior cerebral artery
Infarct of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Infarct of the left posterior cerebral artery
Infarct of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cortex, including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the face and upper extremities. Stroke of the right MCA manifests with contralateral (i.e., left) homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing due to damage to the optic radiations. In addition, patients usually experience contralateral sensory loss and paralysis of the upper extremity, lower extremity, and lower half of the face with gaze deviation towards the side of the stroke. If the stroke occurs in the nondominant (typically the right) hemisphere, patients may also present with hemineglect. This patient has right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, sensory impairment without motor impairment, no gaze deviation, and alexia without agraphia rather than hemineglect, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with ischemic stroke of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) present with Wallenberg syndrome, or lateral medullary syndrome. Occlusion of the left PICA leads to ischemia and necrosis of the left lateral medulla. Patients experience ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, palatal weakness and dysphagia, vertigo, hemiataxia, and contralateral truncal sensory disturbances. This patient has decreased sensation of his right leg rather than right trunk, and the description of his verbal difficulties is more consistent with alexia than dysphagia. He exhibits none of the classic signs and symptoms for a PICA infarct.

C) INCORRECT:

The right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the visual cortex of the occipital lobe. Patients with right-sided PCA stroke present with homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing on the left, not right. Patients with right-sided PCA strokes also often present with prosopagnosia due to damage to the fusiform face area, a symptom not experienced by this patient.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the lower extremities. Patients with stroke of the right ACA present with sensory and motor loss in the contralateral (i.e., left) lower limb; however, this patient has sensory findings in the right lower extremity. In addition, ACA stroke results in limb apraxia, urinary incontinence, dysarthria, and aphasia, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, ACA stroke does not typically result in homonymous hemianopia.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with HSV encephalitis present with a prodrome of headache, fever, nausea, and vomiting, followed by an acute onset of altered mental status, seizures, and psychiatric symptoms or behavioral changes (e.g., hypersexuality, hypomania, agitation). Patients also present with focal neurologic deficits (e.g., dysphasia, ataxia, hemiparesis, cranial nerve signs). Although this patient does have altered mental status, visual field deficits, and memory loss, he does not present with other symptoms of HSV encephalitis.

F) INCORRECT:

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cortex, including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the face and upper extremities. Stroke of the left MCA manifests with contralateral (i.e., right) homonymous hemianopia, typically without macular sparing due to damage to the optic radiations. In addition, patients usually experience contralateral sensory loss and paralysis of the upper extremity, lower extremity, and lower half of the face with gaze deviation towards the side of the stroke. If the stroke occurs in the dominant (typically the left) hemisphere, patients may also present with aphasia. This patient has right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, sensory impairment without motor impairment, no gaze deviation, and alexia without agraphia rather than aphasia, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with ischemic stroke of the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) present with lateral pontine syndrome due to ischemia of the left inferolateral pons, including cranial nerve nuclei. Symptoms include ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, facial paralysis and droop, decreased taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, vertigo, audiovestibular dysfunction, and ataxia. This patient exhibits none of these symptoms.

H) INCORRECT:

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the lower extremities. Patients with stroke of the left ACA present with sensory and motor loss in the contralateral (i.e., right) lower limb, and while this patient does have sensory findings in the right lower extremity, muscle strength is still intact. In addition, ACA stroke results in limb apraxia, urinary incontinence, dysarthria, and aphasia, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, ACA stroke does not typically result in homonymous hemianopia.

I) INCORRECT:

Patients with ischemic stroke of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) present with Wallenberg syndrome, or lateral medullary syndrome. Occlusion of the right PICA leads to ischemia and necrosis of the right lateral medulla. Patients experience ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, palatal weakness and dysphagia, vertigo, hemiataxia, and contralateral truncal sensory disturbances. This patient has decreased sensation of his right leg rather than left trunk, and the description of his verbal difficulties is more consistent with alexia rather than dysphagia. He exhibits none of the classic signs and symptoms for a PICA infarct.

J) CORRECT:

The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the posteroinferior cortex, including the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Stroke in this area most commonly manifests with contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, as seen in this patient, because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery. Because the PCA also supplies the lateral parts of the thalamus, patients may also report contralateral hemisensory abnormalities such as numbness or paresthesia in the limbs, trunk, and/or chest. Further manifestations include memory deficits, vertigo, and nausea. If the PCA of the dominant (usually the left) hemisphere is affected, patients may also present with alexia without agraphia, anomic aphasia, and/or visual agnosia due to ischemic damage to the splenium of the corpus callosum, which carries visual information from the visual cortex to the Broca area and Wernicke area. If the PCA of the nondominant (usually the right) hemisphere is affected, patients may present with prosopagnosia.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

K) INCORRECT:

Patients with ischemic stroke of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) present with lateral pontine syndrome due to ischemia of the right inferolateral pons, including cranial nerve nuclei. Symptoms include ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, facial paralysis and droop, decreased taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, vertigo, audiovestibular dysfunction, and ataxia. This patient exhibits none of these symptoms.

L) INCORRECT:

Patients with ophthalmic or retinal migraine present with headache and monocular visual impairments, such as scotomas, bright flashing lights, or complete monocular blindness. A migraine can cause paresthesias, but is usually preceded by a prodrome of yawning, difficulty writing or reading, mood changes, and, in some cases, an aura. This patient has a headache, but no history of a prodrome prior to this event. In addition, he has bilateral visual impairment rather than unilateral.
questions.hint: This patient has sudden-onset neurologic symptoms, most likely caused by a stroke. He presents with vision loss in the right halves of the visual field (nasal field on the left and temporal field on the right), which is consistent with right-sided homonymous hemianopia. This finding suggests the involvement of the visual pathways behind the optical chiasma.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of his left leg for the past hour. He was unable to get out of bed that morning. His pants are soaked with urine. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Sensation is decreased in the left lower extremity. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time and has a flat affect. When asked to count backwards from 20, he stops after counting to 17. When asked to name 10 words beginning with the letter “d,” he stops after naming two words. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) may manifest with urinary incontinence and behavioral changes including a flattened affect and abulia. However, this condition is a gradually progressive disease, unlike the acute presentation in this patient. Although patients with NPH may have a feeling of weakness and numbness, true sensory deficits or lower limb weakness severe enough to impair movement are not typically seen. Instead, gait abnormalities (typically a shuffling, wide-based gait) are usually the earliest sign.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery would result in lateral medullary syndrome, which is characterized by hoarseness, dysphagia, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral preganglionic Horner's syndrome, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensations over the face ipsilaterally and in the contralateral side of the body. Urinary incontinence, motor deficits, and clinical features of frontal lobe damage are not usually seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A large infarct in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) may result in abulia as well as sensory and motor deficits. However, neurologic deficits would occur in the right limb rather than the left one and are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk when compared to the lower limb. Patients with a left MCA stroke would also have dysphasia.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery results in infarction of the lateral caudal pons and/or ischemia in the territory of the labyrinthine artery. Patients present with ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral preganglionic Horner's syndrome, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensations over the face ipsilaterally and in the contralateral side of the body. Urinary incontinence, motor deficits, and clinical features of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia, flat affect) are not usually seen.

E) INCORRECT:

A large infarct in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) can cause abulia and sensory and motor neurologic deficits on the left side of the body. However, neurologic deficits are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk than in the lower limb. Also, a patient with a massive right MCA stroke would present with left hemineglect (if the right hemisphere is nondominant) or aphasia (if the right hemisphere is dominant).

F) CORRECT:

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial part of the frontal lobe and parietal lobe. These areas provide motor and sensory innervation of the lower extremities as well as control of micturition. Occlusion of the postcommunal segment (distal to the circle of Willis) of the right ACA typically results in upper motor neuron weakness manifesting with a contralateral positive Babinski sign, sensory deficits of the contralateral lower limb, and urinary incontinence. Signs of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia), as well as aphasia and limb apraxia, may also be present.

G) INCORRECT:

A right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in left homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, other features such as prosopagnosia (in individuals where the right hemisphere is the nondominant one) would also be expected.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

H) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) manifests with urinary incontinence and abulia with sensory loss and upper motor neuron weakness in the lower limb (which causes a positive Babinski sign). However, the neurologic deficits in a left ACA stroke would appear in the right lower limb, not the left one.

I) INCORRECT:

Encephalitis that predominantly affects the medial temporal lobe is characteristic of herpes simplex encephalitis, which may manifest with focal neurologic deficits. However, in almost all patients, the onset of neurologic deficits would be preceded by fever, headache, and/or vomiting. Other clinical features such as memory loss, emotional lability, and/or dysphasia would also be present.

J) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive encephalopathy is a hypertensive emergency that occurs in patients with a mean arterial pressure >180 mm Hg and can cause neurologic deficits and nonlocalizing signs of cerebral edema, such as severe headache, nausea, and/or vomiting. Furthermore, hypertensive encephalopathy typically has an insidious onset, in contrast to the acute onset in this patient. Other features such as findings of grade IV hypertensive retinopathy on fundoscopy (flame-shaped hemorrhage, papilledema, and/or cotton wool spots) would also be present.

K) INCORRECT:

A left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in right homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, in a patient with a large left PCA infarct, the contralateral (right not left) limb would be affected, and other clinical features such as alexia without agraphia would be present.
questions.hint: This patient has sudden-onset neurologic symptoms. An inability to complete goal-directed tests such as counting backward from 20 or naming words starting with the letter “d” together with a flat affect indicates abulia, which is usually the result of damage to the frontal lobe.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of weakness in her right arm, leg, and face. Her husband says that she was finishing her breakfast when suddenly her right leg and arm “stopped working properly.” She tried to talk to him but her speech was incoherent. For the past 4 months, she has been more anxious than usual and experienced dizziness on several occasions. She used to exercise regularly but had to give up her exercise routine 3 months ago because of generalized fatigue, and lightheadedness and shortness of breath with exertion. She has a history of hypertension. She takes lisinopril daily and alprazolam as needed. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is a tax accountant and has had increased stress at work recently. On presentation, she is alert and fully oriented; her speech is normal. The patient's pants are soaked with urine. On neurologic examination, she has a slight right facial droop and 4/5 muscle strength in the right arm and leg. Sensation is slightly diminished over the right side of the face and right arm and leg. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Irregularly irregular R-R intervals on electrocardiogram
Ruptured saccular aneurysm on CT angiography of the head
Double lumen of the left-sided carotid artery on duplex ultrasound
Intraparenchymal hyperdensity on CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Irregularly irregular rhythm and absent P waves on ECG are characteristic of atrial fibrillation (Afib). Although the classic signs of Afib include tachycardia and an irregularly irregular pulse, some individuals are asymptomatic or present only with subtle signs of arrhythmia (e.g., palpitations, dizziness, lightheadedness, fatigue, and dyspnea). The uncoordinated atrial contractions lead to blood stasis in the left atrium and atrial appendage, which significantly increases the risk of clot formation and thromboembolic complications. Dislodged emboli can clog several different arteries simultaneously and result in embolic ischemic stroke. Individuals with embolic stroke typically experience maximum severity of symptoms at onset, followed by rapid improvement if the emboli migrate outward allowing arterial recanalization. Embolic stroke from a cardiac source often affects young or middle-aged people with cardiac disease, whereas thrombotic or embolic stroke due to atherosclerosis is more common in older adults with risk factors for atherosclerosis.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to calculate the risk of stroke in patients with Afib. This patient's score is 2 points (female sex, history of hypertension), which puts her at intermediate risk for stroke.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm (examples of the irregular R-R intervals are indicated by red arrows)

– Average ventricular rate ∼ 84/min (14 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes (examples indicated by green lines)

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

B) INCORRECT:

A ruptured saccular aneurysm resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) leads to hemorrhagic stroke. SAH classically manifests with severe headaches (often described by patients as the worst headache they have ever experienced) with a hyperacute onset, other meningeal signs, and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., nausea, vomiting) in addition to focal neurological deficits. In patients with hemorrhagic stroke, these deficits typically worsen as the hematoma expands. In this patient whose symptoms have rapidly improved, an embolic stroke, not a hemorrhagic stroke, is more likely; therefore, another finding would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Valvular vegetations on transthoracic echocardiography are characteristic of bacterial endocarditis (BE), which can cause septic embolization and result in an embolic stroke. Subacute BE can manifest with lightheadedness and dyspnea on exertion for weeks to months. However, most patients with BE present with constitutional symptoms, as well as extracardiac manifestations, such as petechiae, splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and/or Roth spots. In addition, BE typically develops in patients with a history of structural cardiac disease (e.g., rheumatic heart disease, aortic stenosis), prosthetic valves, IV drug use, intravascular devices (e.g., IV catheter), or poor dental hygiene.

D) INCORRECT:

A double lumen of the left-sided carotid artery on duplex ultrasound is consistent with carotid artery dissection (CAD), which can lead to ischemic stroke. However, nonischemic features due to expanding hematoma would be expected, such as ipsilateral headache, facial/neck pain, Horner syndrome, and/or tinnitus. Finally, CAD is typically caused by penetrating or blunt trauma, which this patient has no history of.

E) INCORRECT:

An intraparenchymal hyperdensity on head CT suggests intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). Given this patient's history of hypertension, the index of suspicion for spontaneous ICH should be high. However, ICH causes hemorrhagic stroke typically manifesting with headaches (caused by meningeal irritation/traction) and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., nausea, vomiting) in addition to focal neurological deficits. In patients with hemorrhagic stroke, these deficits typically worsen as the hematoma expands. In this patient whose symptoms have rapidly improved, an embolic stroke, not a hemorrhagic stroke, is more likely; therefore, another finding would be expected.
questions.hint: Right-sided weakness and numbness in the upper and lower limbs, urinary incontinence, and aphasia (incoherent speech) suggest stroke affecting several different vascular territories: the left anterior cerebral artery and left middle cerebral artery. These features in combination with rapid clinical improvement after symptom onset suggest a specific etiology of stroke, which is further supported by the history of fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and lightheadedness.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after his wife noticed that the right side of his face was drooping during breakfast. He had difficulty putting on his shirt and shoes before coming to the hospital. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. He has an implanted insulin pump for blood sugar control. His medications are enalapril and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He drinks one glass of wine daily. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils with gaze deviation towards the left. Visual field testing shows right-sided homonymous hemianopia. Neurologic examination shows a right facial droop. Muscle strength and sensation are decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Plantar reflex testing shows an extensor response on the right side. Speech is dysarthric. There is a bruit on the left side of the neck. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum concentrations of glucose and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Noncontrast CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is an appropriate diagnostic modality in the initial work-up of suspected stroke. However, this patient has an implanted insulin pump, which could be adversely affected by the MRI scanner.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) may be used in the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which typically manifests with a thunderclap headache that rapidly progresses to nausea, vomiting, cardiovascular dysfunction, coma, and then death. SAH can cause stroke, but as this patient lacks the characteristic history of sudden-onset, severe headache that is present in almost all patients with SAH, this diagnosis is less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is used to identify carotid stenosis, for which this patient is at high risk (as suggested by carotid bruit and likely thromboembolic stroke), but the diagnosis and treatment of this patient's suspected stroke takes priority over confirming carotid stenosis; confirmation of carotid stenosis would not affect acute stroke management. Duplex ultrasonography would likely be performed later on in management, once the acute phase of the stroke has been managed.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral angiography (i.e., CTA or MRA) can be used in the diagnosis of stroke and to facilitate in-situ treatment (i.e., mechanical thrombectomy). However, because angiography uses intravasal contrast, hemorrhage should be excluded first. Therefore, a different step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) CORRECT:

An emergency, noncontrast CT scan of the head is the preferred imaging technique to rule out intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in patients with suspected stroke and should be carried out before other management (e.g., thrombolysis). Additionally, a CT scan may detect signs of ischemia (e.g., hypoattenuation or large clots in a blood vessel). CT scans are fast and can significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality of stroke. Although MRI can be used as an alternative for diagnosis, it is inappropriate in this patient because it could adversely affect his implanted insulin pump. If initial imaging is inconclusive but clinical suspicion for ICH is high (e.g., thunderclap headache), a lumbar puncture may be performed to evaluate for signs of the condition (e.g., erythrocytes) in the cerebrospinal fluid.

This patient has several risk factors for stroke (i.e., diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and smoking), and the carotid bruit suggests a thromboembolic ischemic stroke. This patient's presentation (right-sided facial droop, sensory and motor deficit in the right upper and lower extremities, right-sided Babinski sign, gaze deviation towards the left, right-sided homonymous hemianopia, dysarthria) is consistent with ischemia in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
BP: blood pressure
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
DW-MRI: diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging
ECG: electrocardiogram
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
MRI: magnetic resonance imaging
NIHSS: National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale
POC: point-of-care
questions.hint: Acute onset of focal neurologic symptoms should raise concern for stroke, which is a neurologic emergency that requires fast workup.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing weakness of his right arm and leg that began when he woke up 3 hours ago. He did not notice any weakness when he went to bed the night before. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He is alert and oriented to person, time, place. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the right side of the face. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the right side. Sensation is intact. His speech is normal in rate and rhythm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An infarction of which of the following sites is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Posterior limb of the left internal capsule

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Infarction in the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in pure motor stroke, which is the most common lacunar stroke (> 50%). This stroke is often caused by occlusion of the lenticulostriate artery. Patients typically present with contralateral hemiparesis without sensory loss or cortical signs (e.g., aphasia). The most common cause of lacunar stroke is hypertension. An emergency noncontrast CT scan of the head is required to evaluate the patient for possible thrombolytic therapy.

Since the internal capsule also contains somatosensory fibers, some patients with lacunar stroke in the internal capsule may present with sensory loss in addition to hemiparesis. This form of lacunar stroke is referred to as sensorimotor stroke and may be confused with middle cerebral artery stroke.

B) INCORRECT:

Infarction at the base of the pons results in dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome, the least common type of lacunar syndrome. This syndrome typically manifests with dysarthria, dysphagia, facial weakness, and ipsilateral clumsiness (e.g., dysmetria, dysrhythmia, dysdiadochokinesia). This patient lacks the characteristic dysarthria of this syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Infarction of the posterolateral thalamus typically results in pure sensory stroke, which is a classic lacunar stroke. Patients present with contralateral numbness and paresthesia of the face, arm, and leg. This patient's sensation is intact, so the posterolateral thalamus is unlikely to have been affected.

D) INCORRECT:

Infarction of the lateral medulla results in lateral medullary syndrome, also referred to as Wallenberg syndrome. This syndrome is caused by occlusion or stenosis of the vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). Symptoms include ipsilateral Horner syndrome, dysphagia, hemiataxia, loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk and limbs. Because this patient does not have any of these symptoms, the lateral medulla is unlikely to be affected.

E) INCORRECT:

Infarction of the cerebellar vermis results in cerebellar syndrome, which is characterized by ipsilateral symptoms, including gait ataxia, imbalance, truncal ataxia, dysmetria, ocular dysfunction, and vertigo. It would therefore not be consistent with this patient's right-sided symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient presents with unilateral weakness of the face, arm, and leg without any sensory or cortical deficits, the defining features of pure motor hemiparesis, which is caused by a classic lacunar stroke syndrome.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a coworker for right arm weakness and numbness. The symptoms started suddenly 2 hours ago. His coworker also noticed that the patient's face appears to droop on the right side and that his speech sounds slurred. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and peripheral arterial disease. He works as a partner at a law firm and has been under more stress than usual lately. His father died of a stroke at age 70. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He drinks two pints (1130 mL) of whiskey each week. He takes aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin daily. He is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 104 kg (229 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 143/92 mm Hg. He is fully alert and oriented. Neurologic examination shows asymmetry of the face with droop of the lips on the right. There is 3/5 strength in right wrist flexion and extension and right finger abduction. Sensation to light touch and pinprick is reduced throughout the right arm. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus have an increased risk for early-onset atherosclerosis of large vessels, which is a result of nonspecific diabetic vessel damage. Although type 2 diabetes mellitus is an important risk factor for stroke, it is not the strongest one.

B) CORRECT:

Hypertension is the strongest predisposing factor for both ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke. Ischemic stroke is primarily caused by large artery atherosclerosis (for which hypertension is a major risk factor), whereas hemorrhagic stroke is most often due to rupture of vessels that have been damaged by chronic arterial hypertension. The most significant nonmodifiable risk factor is age > 65 years. Other important predisposing factors for ischemic stroke include conditions that increase the thromboembolic risk such as diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation, and carotid artery stenosis. Risk factors for hemorrhagic stroke include conditions that lead to vascular damage, such as vasculitis, malignancy, and previous ischemic stroke.

This patient's risk for hypertension-related stroke is further elevated because his blood pressure is not optimally controlled. According to current recommendations by the American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology, blood pressure should not exceed a maximum of < 130/80 mm Hg in patients with diabetes mellitus.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive, regular consumption of alcohol increases the risk for a number of conditions, which are themselves risk factors for stroke. Alcohol can raise blood pressure, promote insulin resistance, cause obesity, and trigger atrial fibrillation with an increased risk for thromboembolic events. Alcohol hepatotoxicity (e.g., cirrhosis) can also lead to insufficient synthesis of coagulation factors and promote hemorrhagic events. This patient's alcohol use considerably increases his risk for stroke but is not the single strongest predisposing factor.

D) INCORRECT:

A positive family history for stroke suggests a possible genetic predisposition for the development of risk factors for stroke, e.g., familial hypercholesterolemia. However, to what degree an individual is affected physically by a genetic predisposition varies greatly and may not significantly increase the risk for stroke. A positive family history is therefore not the single strongest predisposing factor for stroke.

E) INCORRECT:

How psychological or emotional stress, especially if experienced over long periods of time, increases the risk for stroke is complex and still subject to research. Likely pathomechanisms include inflammatory processes directly affecting the arteries, as well as increased secretion of proinflammatory cytokines which promote the development of atherosclerosis. However, the physical impact of stress varies greatly from person to person and does not have the strongest association with the development of stroke.

F) INCORRECT:

Obesity is both an independent risk factor for cardiovascular disease, including stroke, and is closely associated with a variety of other cardiovascular risk factors. While an important modifiable risk factor, obesity is not the strongest risk factor for stroke.

G) INCORRECT:

Hyperlipidemia can contribute to the development of atherosclerosis by forming plaques in the tunica intima of arterial walls. Atherosclerosis, in turn, causes intraluminal narrowing and obstruction of arteries and may lead to stroke. While an important risk factor for stroke, it is not the strongest one.

H) INCORRECT:

Smoking is an important risk factor for stroke, especially for ischemic stroke and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Smoking causes vascular damage, most likely due to an increase in platelet aggregation and fibrinogen levels, a reduction of HDL cholesterol levels, and direct vascular toxic effects of certain tobacco compounds. Although this patient has a considerable risk of vascular damage due to his long history of tobacco use, smoking alone does not have the strongest association with the development of stroke.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic symptoms (right arm numbness and weakness, facial droop, slurred speech) which is suggestive of stroke in the area of the left middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences, and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Occlusion of the right penetrating arteries
Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery
Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries
Dissection of the right vertebral artery
Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery
Rupture of right posterior cerebral artery malformation
Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Rupture of left posterior cerebral artery malformation
Dissection of the left vertebral artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which manifests with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemia to the right posterior limb of the internal capsule, due to occlusion of right penetrating arteries, would cause left-sided, not right-sided weakness. Furthermore, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

C) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery typically causes left-sided weakness and, if the right hemisphere is nondominant (most individuals), hemineglect. In some, typically left-handed individuals, the language center is located in the right hemisphere. In these patients, a right middle cerebral artery stroke could cause Broca aphasia. However, left-sided, not right-sided, weakness would be expected in this scenario.

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries that supply the left posterior limb of the internal capsule can result in right-sided weakness, as seen in this patient. However, Broca aphasia localizes to the inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the right vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.

F) CORRECT:

Broca aphasia is caused by damage of the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (typically left) hemisphere. This patient additionally has right facial droop, right-sided muscle weakness, and right-sided pronator drift downwards, suggesting an upper motor neuron lesion in the left motor cortex. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the inferior frontal gyrus, as well as the motor cortex. This patient has several risk factors for arteriosclerosis and, therefore, ischemic stroke (hypertension, age > 65 years, diabetes mellitus), making occlusion of the left MCA the most likely cause of his focal neurologic deficits.

Ischemic strokes do not typically cause headaches, whereas hemorrhagic strokes usually manifest with severe headaches.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

G) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage into the right posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a right posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause left-sided, but not right-sided weakness. Rupture of this artery would also cause left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present in this patient. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

H) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which presents with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

I) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage into the left posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a left posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause right-sided hemiparesis, as seen in this patient. However, rupture of this artery would also cause right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present here. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

J) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the left vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits that are consistent with stroke. Telegraphic speech (as evidenced by the use of short, simple sentences), intact comprehension (as evidenced by the ability to follow commands), and impaired repetition of word sequences are consistent with Broca aphasia. The presence of this type of language deficit helps localize the damage to a specific region of the cortex.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache and left-sided weakness and numbness for the past 2 hours. She has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril, amlodipine, insulin, and warfarin. She is oriented to person, place, and date. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.3°F), pulse is 90/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 165/94 mm Hg. Examination shows leftward and downward deviation of the eyes. The pupils are miotic and nonreactive. Muscle strength is 2/5 on the left side and 5/5 on the right side. Deep tendon reflexes are decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased on the left side and normal on the right side and the face. Prothrombin time is 51 seconds (INR = 4.3). Hemorrhage into which of the following locations is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar hemorrhage typically manifests with ataxia, dysarthria, facial palsy, and skew deviation of the eyes. Signs of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, neck stiffness) occur early. Hemiparesis, which this patient presents with, is characteristically absent in cerebellar strokes, indicating that another area of her brain is likely affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Putaminal hemorrhage (from anterolateral central arteries) typically manifests with contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemisensory defects, and contralateral gaze palsy with an ipsilateral deviation of the eyes. Therefore, a right-sided putaminal hemorrhage can manifest with left-sided hemiplegia and hemisensory loss. However, a left-sided gaze palsy with a rightward deviation of the eyes would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Pontine hemorrhage typically manifests with quadriplegia, facial paralysis, deafness, and dysarthria. Furthermore, miotic pupils are a feature of pontine stroke. However, affected individuals have ipsilateral horizontal conjugate palsy (i.e., an inability to horizontally look toward the side of the lesion) or, in bilateral pontine hemorrhage, ocular bobbing. Vertical eye movements and blinking are preserved in ventral pontine stroke, a condition known as locked-in syndrome. This patient has almost none of the typical features of pontine hemorrhage.


D) INCORRECT:

Putaminal hemorrhage typically manifests with contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemisensory loss, and contralateral gaze palsy with ipsilateral deviation of the eyes. A left-sided putaminal hemorrhage can manifest with leftward deviation of the eyes. However, right-sided hemiplegia and hemisensory loss would also be expected.

E) CORRECT:

The combination of hemiparesis, hemisensory deficits, miotic and nonreactive pupils, and gaze deviation downward and toward the affected side of the body (i.e., away from the side of the brain lesion) is a phenomenon known as “wrong way eyes” and characteristically occurs in thalamic hemorrhage. In contrast, other sites of supratentorial hemorrhage typically cause a gaze deviation toward the side of the lesion (i.e., away from the affected side of the body). This patient’s left-sided weakness and sensory loss, miotic nonreactive pupils, and leftward and downward deviation of her eyes are best explained by a stroke in the right thalamus.

Note that the thalamus is a relatively large region of the brain and thalamic stroke has a variety of manifestations (e.g., pure sensory stroke in lacunar syndromes). However, “wrong way eyes” is a classical finding of thalamic hemorrhage.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of an older adult

Hyperdense hemorrhage (blue overlay) involving the right thalamus extends to the posterior limb of the right internal capsule. Intraventricular hemorrhage (yellow overlay) is also present. Mass-effect has caused a slight midline shift.

Prominent sulci and ventricles are consistent with cerebral atrophy.

Green overlay: internal capsule; red line: midline; T: thalamus

F) INCORRECT:

A frontal lobe hemorrhage typically manifests with weakness or paralysis of the contralateral leg (sparing the arm) and deviation of the eyes toward the side of the lesion. Although a hemorrhagic stroke in the left frontal lobe can manifest with a leftward deviation of the eyes, right-sided weakness of the lower limb would also be present. In addition, sensation is typically preserved in frontal lobe lesions. Thus, another area of the brain is more likely to be affected in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

A frontal lobe hemorrhage typically manifests with weakness or paralysis of the contralateral leg (sparing the arm) and deviation of the eyes toward the side of the lesion. Sensation is typically preserved in frontal lobe lesions. A right frontal lobe hemorrhage would manifest with weakness in the left leg but also with rightward deviation of the eyes, whereas this patient's eyes deviate leftward.

H) INCORRECT:

Thalamic hemorrhage typically manifests with contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, miotic and unreactive pupils, and upgaze palsy with gaze deviation away from the side of the lesion, a phenomenon known as “wrong way eyes”. A hemorrhagic lesion in the left thalamus would manifest with right-sided weakness and sensory loss with rightward gaze deviation, unlike what is seen in this case.
questions.hint: Hemorrhage in this region may extend into the third ventricle.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with hypertension and atrial fibrillation is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset visual changes. He stopped taking all of his medications 2 months ago. Blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg and pulse is 108/min. He is alert and oriented to person but does not follow commands. His speech is fluent with normal cadence, but he uses frequent non-existent words and the content of his speech is nonsensical. He appears unaware of his speech impairment. He is unable to read a text out loud. Peripheral vision is diminished in the right upper visual fields bilaterally. This patient's presentation is most consistent with injury to which of the following labeled areas?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Region A corresponds with the hippocampus, which is involved in the limbic system and is important for memory formation; it is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery and is particularly vulnerable to ischemia. Ischemic stroke involving the hippocampus would result in anterograde amnesia rather than the fluent aphasia and visual field defects seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Region B corresponds with the internal capsule and is a common site of lacunar infarcts, which classically present with contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia; dysarthria and dysphagia may also be present. This patient has significant risk factors for a lacunar infarct (e.g., age and unmanaged hypertension), but his receptive aphasia and right upper homonymous quadrantanopsia are not consistent with an internal capsule infarct.

C) INCORRECT:

Region C corresponds with the insula, a complex structure involved in perception, somatosensory processing, visceromotor functions, and cognition. Ischemic injury to this region is extremely rare and can have variable presentation, including vestibular, motor, somatosensory, speech, and/or cardiac conduction abnormalities. Insular strokes are most commonly associated with nonfluent aphasia; the combination of a fluent, receptive aphasia and right upper homonymous quadrantanopsia in this patient is not consistent with an insular stroke.

D) INCORRECT:

Region D corresponds with the inferior frontal gyrus, which is an important region for language and comprehension and is supplied by the superior division of the MCA. Ischemic stroke involving the inferior frontal gyrus classically manifests with Broca aphasia, which is characterized by nonfluent speech deficits and relative sparing of comprehension. This patient has evidence of fluent aphasia, making injury to the inferior frontal gyrus unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of Wernicke aphasia and right upper homonymous quadrantanopsia is most consistent with an ischemic injury to the superior temporal gyrus (region E) due to an ischemic stroke involving the inferior division of the left MCA. His visual field deficits are the result of the involvement of the inferior fascicle of the left optic radiations (Meyer loop) in the temporal lobe. His atrial fibrillation and medical nonadherence suggest a thromboembolic stroke as the underlying cause.
questions.hint: This patient's receptive aphasia, right upper homonymous quadrantanopsia, and CVA risk factors are concerning for stroke secondary to occlusion of the inferior division of the left MCA.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of slurred speech 1 hour ago. Physical examination shows drooling and hypernasal speech. His face is symmetric and strength is 5/5 in all extremities. This patient's presentation is most consistent with injury to which of the labeled areas of the primary motor cortex?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This area of the motor homunculus corresponds with the motor innervation of the muscles of the throat involved in swallowing, as well as the tongue, mastication, and vocalization. Slurred speech and drooling are signs of injury to this area, most likely due to an ischemic stroke.
Image Description:

The motor homunculus is a map of the primary motor cortex (located in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobes) that illustrates which areas of the brain process the motor output to which part of the body. The distorted representation of the body and the size of the correspondingly labeled cortical areas illustrate the proportional amount of motor output sent to the individual parts of the body. Accordingly, since areas like the tongue, face, and hands receive most motor innervation, these areas are represented as disproportionately large compared to other areas, like the trunk and lower limbs.

B) INCORRECT:

This corresponds to the region of the motor homunculus that is responsible for facial expressions. This patient's face is symmetric, and his drooling and hypernasal speech suggest the involvement of a different labeled area.

C) INCORRECT:

This corresponds to the region of the motor homunculus that is responsible for the movement of the index finger. This patient does not present with impaired index finger function.

D) INCORRECT:

This corresponds to the region of the motor homunculus that is responsible for the movement of the wrist. This patient does not present with impaired wrist flexion/extension or adduction/abduction

E) INCORRECT:

This corresponds to the region of the motor homunculus that is responsible for the movement of the toe. This patient does not present with toe or foot paralysis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of an ischemic stroke. His slurred speech and drooling indicate pathological changes in the cortical area responsible for the central control of swallowing and vocalization. The motor homunculus represents all parts of the body arranged medially to laterally.

questions.text: A 78-year-old right-handed man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department for sudden onset of nausea and vertigo 1 hour ago. Physical examination shows 5/5 strength in all extremities. Sensation to light touch and pinprick is decreased in the right arm and leg. A CT scan of the brain shows an acute infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left-sided hemineglect would be consistent with damage to the right parietal lobe (e.g., due to a right middle cerebral artery stroke), which is usually associated with contralateral motor and sensory deficits. In this patient, a posterior cerebral artery stroke was diagnosed and no motor deficits are present.

B) CORRECT:

The posterior cerebral artery supplies parts of the thalamus and the visual cortex within the occipital lobe. In addition to contralateral hemisensory loss due to lateral thalamic infarction (as seen in this patient), occlusion to the posterior cerebral artery causes damage to the visual cortex that results in contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. Central vision is not impaired in posterior cerebral artery infarction since the corresponding cortical area of the macula is supplied by the middle cerebral artery.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

C) INCORRECT:

Gaze deviation towards the side of infarction (in this case: left-sided gaze deviation) combined with contralateral sensory loss, as seen in this patient, would be consistent with infarction of the left middle cerebral artery, which supplies the frontal eye field. Affected patients are also likely to present with right-sided motor dysfunction and aphasia. This patient, however, presents with posterior cerebral artery stroke.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

D) INCORRECT:

Prosopagnosia is most commonly seen with right posterior cerebral artery strokes (e.g., infarction of the right occipitotemporal lobe). This would not be an expected finding in a patient with a left posterior cerebral artery stroke, as seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Right upper homonymous quadrantanopia would suggest a lesion in the left optic radiation and can be seen in strokes involving the left middle cerebral artery. This finding would not be expected in a patient with a posterior cerebral artery stroke.
questions.hint: The posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with hypertension and congenital blindness comes to the physician because he is unable to recognize objects by touch with his right hand. The symptoms started about 2 hours ago. When given a house key, he can feel the object in his right hand but is not able to identify what it is. This patient's condition is most likely caused by a lesion in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere encompasses the Broca area, which is involved in speech production. A lesion in the Broca area causes expressive aphasia, not astereognosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The superior temporal gyrus consists of the primary auditory cortex and auditory association cortex, which is part of Wernicke area in the dominant hemisphere. A lesion in this area causes slight loss of hearing, difficulty of sound localization, and Wernicke aphasia if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

C) CORRECT:

The somatosensory association cortex is located in the superior parietal lobule and is involved in tactile information processing and spatial orientation. A lesion in the left superior parietal lobule can cause contralateral (i.e. right-sided in this case) astereognosis. Hemispatial neglect can also result from parietal lobe damage; however, it is more characteristic of right parietal lobe lesions, rather than the left parietal lobe lesion seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

The precentral gyrus is the location of the primary motor cortex, which controls the motor function of the contralateral body. A lesion in this area leads to contralateral spastic paralysis, not astereognosis.

E) INCORRECT:

The cingulate gyrus is part of the limbic system, which is involved in emotion, feeding, mating, learning, and memory formation. Decreased volume of the anterior cingulate gyrus has been associated with a lowered level of social functioning in patients with schizophrenia. A cingulate gyrus lesion does not cause astereognosis.
questions.hint: The ability to recognize objects by touch is called stereognosis. Tactile information is processed by the secondary somatosensory cortex (somatosensory association cortex).

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with hypertension and coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of right-sided weakness. Her pulse is 83/min and blood pressure is 156/90 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows right-sided lower facial drooping and complete paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities. Tongue position is normal and she is able to swallow liquids without difficulty. Sensation to vibration, pain, position, and light touch is normal bilaterally. She is oriented to person, place, and time, and is able to speak normally. Occlusion of which of the following vessels is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would cause motor deficits. However, the motor deficit would predominantly affect the lower extremity and sensory deficits in the lower extremity would also be expected. The upper extremity is usually spared or only mildly affected and the face would be spared. Moreover, an ipsilateral (right) ACA infarct would produce deficits on the contralateral (left) side.

B) INCORRECT:

The anterior spinal artery (ASA) and vertebral artery supply the medial regions of the lower medulla. Occlusion of the ASA at the level of the brainstem can therefore damage the corticospinal tract and cause motor deficits. However, facial palsy would not be expected since this facial nerve nucleus arises in the lateral region of the upper medulla. Moreover, patients would also have impaired pain and proprioception (due to damage to the medial lemniscus) and features of hypoglossal nerve palsy (e.g., inability to protrude the tongue, tongue deviation).

C) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) causes contralateral motor deficits similar to the ones seen in this patient. However, occlusion of the entire MCA would cause additional symptoms, such as sensory changes, gaze deviation, and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere). In this patient, only a branch of the MCA is affected.

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome), which is characterized by ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ipsilateral cerebellar signs (e.g., hemiataxia), impaired pain and temperature sensation in the contralateral body and ipsilateral face, and features of ipsilateral cranial nerve IX, X, and XI palsy (e.g., dysphagia, dysphonia). This patient with pure motor deficits in one half of the body would not have Wallenberg syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

A pure motor stroke is caused by infarction in the posterior limb of the internal capsule, which contains the corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers that innervate the motor nuclei on the contralateral side. Therefore, a lesion at this site can cause contralateral hemiplegia as well as weakness in the lower half of the face because the region of the facial nerve nucleus that supplies the lower half of the face only receives unilateral corticobulbar innervation. Other cranial nerve nuclei as well as the region of the facial nerve nucleus that innervates the forehead receive bilateral corticobulbar innervation and are therefore spared. The most common cause of stroke in this region is a lacunar stroke of the lenticulostriate artery (a branch of the middle cerebral artery).
