Since the internal capsule also contains somatosensory fibers, some patients with lacunar stroke in the internal capsule may present with sensory loss in addition to hemiparesis. This form of lacunar stroke is referred to as sensorimotor stroke and may be confused with middle cerebral artery stroke.
Image Description:

Fibers of the pyramidal tract originate from the primary motor cortex and descend to the brain stem via the internal capsule. Bulbar corticonuclear fibers extend to each of the cranial nerve nuclei, which innervate the facial muscles. The remaining fibers descend from the brainstem as two divisions of the corticospinal tract. Approximately 80% of these fibers decussate at the level of the medulla (pyramidal decussation) to the contralateral side to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They then descend into the spinal cord to innervate the limbs and digits. The remaining approximately 20% of fibers descend from the brainstem ipsilaterally, forming the anterior corticospinal tract. These decussate at the spinal level of the trunk muscles they innervate.
questions.hint: This patient has features of a pure motor stroke without any sensory deficits or cortical signs (e.g., aphasia, agnosia, apraxia). The lesion is most likely located in the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because she thinks he has had a stroke. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril and metformin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 35 years. His blood pressure is 162/95 mm Hg. A CT scan of the brain shows a lacunar stroke involving the left subthalamic nucleus. The patient most likely presented with which of the following findings on physical examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cogwheel rigidity is typically seen in Parkinson disease, which is caused by progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. A lacunar stroke of the subthalamic nucleus is unlikely to present with cogwheel rigidity.

B) INCORRECT:

Dystonia can be seen secondary to lesions of the thalamus, the putamen, or the globus pallidus. A lacunar stroke of the subthalamic nucleus is unlikely to present with dystonia.

C) CORRECT:

Contralateral hemiballismus and choreiform movements are common symptoms of a lacunar infarct of the subthalamic nucleus. They are caused by a reduction in the activity of the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia. Lacunar infarcts are noncortical infarcts, characterized by the absence of cortical signs. Subthalamic strokes are usually ischemic in etiology, and uncontrolled hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and a significant smoking history are known risk factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Truncal ataxia is usually seen in lesions of the cerebellar vermis. Other signs that can be seen in a cerebellar stroke include dysarthria, dysmetria, and oculomotor disorders (nystagmus). A lacunar stroke of the subthalamic nucleus is unlikely to present with truncal ataxia.

E) INCORRECT:

Vertical gaze palsy is usually caused by midbrain lesions, e.g., dorsal midbrain syndrome, and can present with vertical gaze palsy, dissociation of pupillary response to light and accommodation, and/or convergence-retraction nystagmus. Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus, on the other hand, are unlikely to cause vertical gaze palsy.

F) INCORRECT:

Hemispatial agnosia is unlikely to be seen in this patient, as it is caused by lesions of the non-dominant parietal cortex, not the subthalamic nucleus. Also, this patient's lesion is on the left side, whereas hemispatial agnosia usually affects the nondominant (typically the right) parietal cortex.
questions.hint: The patient's wife could have been injured if she had been standing nearby when the patient was having the stroke.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset right-sided body numbness for 1 hour. He reports that he has a 15-year history of hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. He is right-handed. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation to light pinprick and temperature on the right side of the face and body. Motor strength is 5/5 and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Perfusion of which of the following structures of the brain is most likely impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of one of its blood-supplying vessels, predominantly the anterior cerebral artery (ACA), and middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of the ACA or MCA may result in numbness. However, a stroke typically on the nondominant (usually right) side would manifest with symptoms of contralateral (left-sided) neglect, while infarction of the dominant (usually left) side would manifest with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia, none of which are present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule occurs due to hemorrhage or occlusion of the lenticulostriate arteries, which supply blood to the greater part of the internal capsule. As fibers of the corticospinal tract pass downward through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, infarction of the posterior limb usually leads to a pure motor stroke with hemiparesis of the leg, arm, and face contralateral to the site of the lesion. Rarely, ischemia of the posterior limb of the internal capsule manifests with isolated contralateral sensory loss, but this is not the most likely etiology of this patient's pure sensory stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Diminished perfusion of the lateral medulla occurs due to occlusion of either the posterior inferior cerebellar artery or branches of the vertebral artery. Infarction of the lateral medulla causes Wallenberg syndrome, which manifests with numbness of the leg and arm contralateral to the lesion. However, patients would also have vestibulocerebellar symptoms, bulbar muscle weakness, and facial paresthesias ipsilateral to the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoperfusion of the basal pons results from occlusion of the penetrating arteries, eventually leading to the development of dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome. Patients present with facial weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria, and weakness of the hand ipsilateral to the site of the lesion; sensory deficits are absent.

E) CORRECT:

A pure sensory stroke is caused by diminished perfusion of the ventral posterolateral nucleus and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus, which relays sensory information of proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals generally present with unilateral sensory deficits of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus). Chronic hypertension and the resulting lipohyalinosis of small vessels are major risk factors for lacunar infarctions including thalamic strokes.

F) INCORRECT:

Hypoperfusion of the subthalamic nucleus leads to contralateral hemiballismus, not sensory deficits.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (right-sided hemisensory loss) and risk factor for atherosclerosis (hypertension) suggest that he has a pure sensory stroke.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset of difficulty speaking for 1 hour. He has hypertension, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. He is 213 cm (7 ft) tall. On examination, the patient speaks slowly in simple sentences that consist of only one word. He seems to have difficulties understanding grammatically complex sentences and appears to be frustrated at the inability to speak fluently. He is able to follow commands. When another individual tries to enter the room, the physician asks the patient to “hold the door,” and he does so immediately. Based on his symptoms, which of the following labeled areas in the schematic overview of a normal brain is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area A, the premotor cortex, is associated with difficulty of planning, initiating, and maintaining muscle movements despite no presence of muscle weakness (apraxia) along with difficulties using sensory feedback for the control of movement. Hence, patients with premotor cortex lesions may be unable to execute motor movements needed to produce speech (verbal apraxia). Verbal apraxia is a disorder of speech articulation, characterized by halting speech and speech sound distortions and errors. This patient, however, has difficulty with language expression.

B) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area B, the primary motor cortex, manifests with contralateral hemiplegia or hemiparesis as well as dysarthria due to a motor dysfunction of the facial muscles and tongue muscles. This results in typical pathologic speech patterns such as slurring, mumbling, and changes in speed and pitch. However, this patient has difficulty with language expression, not with the production of speech sounds.

C) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area C, the primary somatosensory cortex, causes contralateral numbness, tingling, and partial sensory loss, which this patient does not have. Moreover, primary somatosensory cortex lesions would not affect speech production.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's nonfluent, telegraphic speech pattern with constant repetition of one word, in combination with preserved comprehension of simple sentences and commands, is characteristic of Broca aphasia (expressive aphasia). An ischemic stroke involving area D, the Broca area, in the dominant (usually left) hemisphere results in expressive aphasia. Affected individuals typically appear frustrated by their speech deficits. Language comprehension is relatively intact as long as the Wernicke area in the temporal lobe is unaffected, although there may be difficulties understanding grammatically complex speech. Broca aphasia due to cerebral infarction may occur as an isolated finding or can be accompanied by contralateral, brachiofacial sensorimotor hemiparesis.

Taking into account this patient's cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus), his symptoms are likely the result of an acute ischemic stroke. This patient's tall stature could result from underlying homocystinuria, which predisposes to thromboses and atherosclerosis, and subsequent stroke. However, he lacks other features of homocystinuria, which include osteoporosis, lens dislocation, and a Marfanoid habitus with long, thin extremities.
Image Description:

The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.

The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.

Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

E) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area E, the primary auditory cortex, can cause difficulty in sound localization and subtle hearing dysfunction if the injury is unilateral or it can cause cortical deafness with complete loss of comprehension if the injury is severe and bilateral. However, this patient's hearing is intact.

F) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area F, the Wernicke area, causes Wernicke aphasia, which is characterized by markedly impaired comprehension, neologisms, long and grammatically correct but nonsensical sentences, and a lack of insight regarding the condition. This patient, however, expresses frustration at his speech impairment, showing insight and can understand simple sentences.

G) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area G, the primary visual cortex, causes cortical blindness with macular sparing, not aphasia.
questions.hint: In response to further questioning, the patient says, “Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor.”

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of left-sided body weakness and involuntary urinary leakage. He has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia treated with metformin and atorvastatin. He reports having experienced a similar episode two years ago. Neurologic examination shows left-sided hemiparesis and decreased sensation. The neurologic abnormalities are more prominent in the left lower than in the left upper extremity. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following labeled vessels in the MR angiography image of a normal brain is most likely occluded in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The right anterior cerebral artery (structure A) supplies the right anteromedial cortex including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes. ACA occlusion causes loss of contralateral motor and sensory function, particularly of the lower extremities. The ACA also supplies the medial frontal micturition center, the part of the brain responsible for bladder control.

B) INCORRECT:

The left anterior cerebral artery (structure B) supplies the left anteromedial cortex including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes. Occlusion would cause the symptoms of motor and sensory loss of the lower extremity seen in this patient, albeit on the right (i.e., contralateral) rather than the left side.

C) INCORRECT:

The right middle cerebral artery (structure C) supplies the right lateral cortex including the temporal lobe and the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobe. Although occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery can manifest with left-sided sensorimotor deficits, the face and upper extremities are typically affected rather than the lower extremities. Moreover, it also causes gaze deviation and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere), which are absent in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The left middle cerebral artery (structure D) supplies the left lateral cortex including the temporal lobe and the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobe. Although occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery can manifest with sensorimotor deficits, symptoms would be expected on the right (i.e., contralateral) rather than the left side. Moreover, unlike this patient, the face and upper extremities are typically affected rather than the lower extremities. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of MCA occlusion such as gaze deviation and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere).
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

E) INCORRECT:

The right posterior cerebral artery (structure E) supplies most parts of the right occipital cortex, the posteromedial aspects of the temporal lobe, and the thalamus. Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) typically manifests with visual field defects, contralateral hemisensory loss, and vertigo. Occlusion of the right PCA may also cause visual recognition deficits (prosopagnosia). Although this patient has left-sided sensory deficits, PCA occlusion would not explain his hemiparesis or incontinence. He also lacks the visual deficits and vertigo typically seen in PCA strokes.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

F) INCORRECT:

The left posterior cerebral artery (structure F) supplies most parts of the left occipital cortex, the posteromedial aspects of the temporal lobe, and the thalamus. Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) typically manifests with visual field defects, contralateral hemisensory loss, and vertigo. Occlusion of the PCA can also cause language deficits (alexia, anomic aphasia). Although this patient does have sensory deficits, a PCA occlusion would not explain his hemiparesis and incontinence. His symptoms are also left-sided, as opposed to the right-sided deficits expected in an occlusion of the left PCA.

G) INCORRECT:

The basilar artery (structure G) is formed by the confluence of the two vertebral arteries at the central groove of the pons and supplies the lower half of the cerebellum, the lower midbrain, the lower pons, the medulla, and the corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts. Basilar artery occlusion can present with vertigo, tinnitus, visual deficits, gait ataxia, and ipsilateral cranial nerve deficits with paresthesias and hemiplegia. Rarely, it can cause locked-in syndrome. Although this patient presents with sensorimotor deficits, there is no evidence of cranial nerve or cerebellar involvement. Moreover, basilar artery occlusion would not explain the urinary incontinence seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Sudden onset of urinary incontinence in conjunction with sensory and motor loss predominantly affecting the left lower extremity should raise concern for cortical injury in the region of the anterior cerebral artery.

questions.text: A 69-year-old right-handed man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. On questioning, he has had some difficulty speaking for 3 months. During a conversation, he often has difficulty repeating what his interlocutor has said. He has hypertension and takes hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits. The patient speaks fluently in full sentences and demonstrates normal comprehension. When asked to say the word “kindergarten,” he replies with, “Sintelmarvin… no, that's wrong…kinterflargin, no that isn't it either...kantolargen...no? How about, kindergarten?” The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is occlusion of a branch of which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the right posterior cerebral artery would cause left-sided weakness and left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing; it would not cause conductive aphasia.

B) CORRECT:

In a right-handed person, the supramarginal gyrus is supplied by a branch of the left middle cerebral. A lesion to this area can disrupt the arcuate fasciculus and result in conductive aphasia.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

C) INCORRECT:

In a right-handed person, occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery would cause left-sided weakness and hemineglect; it would not cause conductive aphasia. In some left-handed individuals, the language center is located in the right hemisphere. In these patients, a lesion to the right middle cerebral artery could cause conductive aphasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Ischemia to the right posterior limb of the internal capsule due to occlusion of right penetrating arteries would cause left-sided weakness; it would not cause conductive aphasia.

E) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which presents with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Conduction aphasia is not seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the right vertebral artery can cause dizziness along with other neurologic signs such as diplopia, hemiparesis, or numbness. It would not manifest with conductive aphasia.

G) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which presents with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Conduction aphasia is not seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

H) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left posterior cerebral artery would cause right-sided hemiparesis and a right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing; it would not cause conductive aphasia.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

I) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left vertebral artery can cause dizziness along with other neurologic signs such as diplopia, hemiparesis, or numbness. It would not manifest with conductive aphasia.

J) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries that supply the left posterior limb of the internal capsule would result in right-sided weakness; it would not cause conductive aphasia.
questions.hint: The patient's impaired repetition with paraphasia, together with preserved comprehension, is called conduction aphasia. Lesions in the supramarginal gyrus can cause this syndrome, which often presents without other neurologic symptoms.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after the sudden onset of speech difficulties and right-sided arm and leg weakness. Examination shows paralysis and hypoesthesia on the right side, positive Babinski sign on the right, and slurred speech. A CT scan of the head shows a hyperdensity in the left middle cerebral artery and no evidence of intracranial bleeding. The patient's symptoms improve rapidly after pharmacotherapy is initiated and his weakness completely resolves. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rivaroxaban, a direct factor Xa inhibitor, is used for the prevention of ischemic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and the treatment of venous thromboembolism, to name a few indications. Despite its prophylactic value, it has no role in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke. Hence, it is unlikely to be given to this patient with an acute ischemic stroke.

B) CORRECT:

Alteplase, a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, is the mainstay of treatment to salvage ischemic tissue in acute ischemic stroke. This drug converts plasminogen to plasmin, which dissolves clots by degrading fibrin. Alteplase is typically administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset but can be used later under specialist guidance. Important contraindications include acute intracranial hemorrhage, recent surgery, severe uncontrolled hypertension, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Heparin is used for the acute treatment of several conditions such as venous thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism, and STEMI. It activates antithrombin III in a manner that inhibits both thrombin and factor X. Early use of heparin in acute ischemic stroke has been associated with higher mortality and worse outcomes as compared to other anticoagulants.

D) INCORRECT:

Prasugrel, a platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor, is given to patients with acute coronary syndrome and for those undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (to prevent coronary stent thrombosis). The drug inhibits platelet aggregation by preventing the expression of Gp IIb/IIIa receptors on the platelet surface. Prasugrel is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or TIA because of the increased risk of significant or fatal bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist used for the prophylaxis of ischemic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, and as treatment for patients with venous thromboembolism. It inhibits hepatic epoxide reductase, thereby blocking synthesis (recycling) of the active, reduced form of vit. K. Without reduced vit. K, γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues cannot occur, which reduces the production of active coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as anticoagulatory proteins C and S. Because this drug takes days to exert and remove its clinically significant anticoagulatory effect, it is primarily used for chronic anticoagulation and has no use in the acute setting.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms in combination with the CT results (hyperdense occluded vessel) indicate an ischemic stroke caused by an obstructive lesion in the left middle cerebral artery. The drug administered can also be used to treat patients with early myocardial infarctions or unstable patients with a pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of right-sided body weakness. His wife reports that he does not seem to understand simple questions. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. The patient speaks fluently, but he answers questions with nonsensical phrases and cannot repeat single words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Broca aphasia is caused by lesions in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere (e.g., due to an infarct in the superior division of the middle cerebral artery). In patients with Broca aphasia, language production is greatly affected, resulting in nonfluent, telegraphic, and grammatically incorrect speech, whereas this patient speaks fluently. Patients with Broca aphasia are aware of their impaired speech and can become frustrated during the physical examination, but this patient is unaware of his language deficits. Inability to repeat single words and impaired language comprehension are not typically seen in Broca aphasia.

B) INCORRECT:

Conduction aphasia is usually caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus. This type of aphasia is characterized by impaired repetition with fluent speech and intact comprehension. This patient has poor repetition with fluent speech but impaired comprehension.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcortical motor aphasia is characterized by nonfluent aphasia with good comprehension and intact repetition. This patient speaks fluently but has impaired comprehension and poor repetition.

D) INCORRECT:

Global aphasia is a neurologic insult that involves nonfluent aphasia and impaired comprehension. Global aphasia is usually caused by a large lesion affecting the Broca area, the Wernicke area, and the arcuate fasciculus. This patient has impaired comprehension and repetition but speaks fluently.

E) CORRECT:

Wernicke aphasia is caused by lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, usually along the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) distribution. Patients with Wernicke aphasia typically present with impaired repetition and language comprehension; although they can speak fluently, they produce nonsensical phrases. Furthermore, these patients lack awareness of their impairment, as is the case here. In addition to Wernicke aphasia, signs of an MCA stroke include gaze deviation towards the side of the infarction and contralateral homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing.

See “Types of aphasia” table.
Image Description:

The different types of aphasia can be divided by the presence of good or poor comprehension (red versus blue), good or poor repetition (top three versus bottom three), as well as nonfluent or fluent (light grey versus dark grey).

F) INCORRECT:

Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterized by impaired comprehension with intact repetition and fluent speech. This patient has fluent speech with impaired comprehension, but his repetition is poor.

G) INCORRECT:

Anomic aphasia is a type of expressive aphasia characterized by word-finding difficulties, particularly in relation to nouns and verbs. Patients with anomic aphasia usually have fluent speech and intact comprehension. This patient speaks fluently but has impaired comprehension and poor repetition.
questions.hint: Sudden onset of right-sided body weakness in conjunction with meaningless speech and impaired comprehension should raise concern for a cerebral lesion located in the posterior part of the left superior temporal gyrus (i.e., occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery).

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he fell from the roof of his house. On arrival, he is unresponsive to verbal and painful stimuli. His pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head shows a fracture in the anterior cranial fossa and a 1-cm laceration in the left anterior orbital gyrus. If the patient survives, which of the following would ultimately be the most common cell type at the injured region of the frontal lobe?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schwann cells are support cells within the nervous system that facilitate the regeneration of damaged nerves. However, they are solely found in the peripheral nervous system.

B) INCORRECT:

Neurons are outnumbered by glial cells in the brain. Furthermore, neurons are post-mitotic and therefore cannot carry out mitosis in response to neuronal damage.

C) CORRECT:

Following CNS damage (e.g., stroke, traumatic brain injury), astrocytes at the margin of the damaged region proliferate and enlarge (reactive gliosis) to form a permanent glial scar. The process of reactive gliosis usually begins 1–2 weeks after the injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Microglia, which are the macrophages of the brain, are activated in response to brain injury. They would phagocytose the dead neuronal tissue, but they would not be a major component of the glial scar that ultimately forms at the site of injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibroblasts, which synthesize collagen, are important for healing and scar formation following injury. However, fibroblasts would not be the most common cell type in scar tissue within the CNS.

F) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrocytes are part of the supportive tissue of the CNS and are important for remyelinating damaged axons. However, oligodendrocytes are not the most common cell type of the glial scar that ultimately forms at the site of injury.
questions.hint: These cells are derived from the neuroectoderm, are GFAP-positive and are a component of the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of hoarseness. Her pulse is 85/min and blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a diminished gag reflex and loss of pain and temperature over the left face and right trunk and extremities. There is no facial asymmetry and the tongue does not deviate when protruded. Her strength is 5/5 bilaterally in both the upper and lower extremities. Ophthalmologic examination shows involuntary, rhythmic ocular movements. There is left-sided miosis and ptosis. This patient's condition is most likely caused by occlusion of which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The basilar artery supplies the ventromedial parts of the pons, caudal midbrain, and rostral medulla via its paramedian and circumferential branches. The clinical features of basilar artery occlusion (BAO) vary depending on the site at which the basilar artery is occluded. Presentations specific to BAO include inferior medial pontine syndrome (Foville syndrome) and locked-in syndrome. Foville syndrome manifests as middle alternating hemiplegia (ipsilateral lateral rectus palsy due to CN VI palsy and contralateral hemiparesis due to corticospinal tract damage) and contralateral loss of fine touch, proprioception, and vibration sensations (due to medial lemniscus damage). Locked-in syndrome manifests as quadriplegia and bulbar palsy with preserved consciousness, blinking, and vertical eye movements. This patient's clinical features allow the infarct to be localized to the lateral medulla, which receives blood from a different vessel.

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of a posterior cerebral artery can cause infarction of the rostral midbrain, thalamus, and/or occipital lobe ipsilaterally and manifest as unilateral ptosis (due to infarction of the CN III nucleus and/or hypothalamospinal tract) and unilateral sensory deficits of the trunk and extremities (due to infarction of the ventral posterolateral nucleus or the ascending sensory tracts), which are seen here. However, all types of sensations (not just pain and temperature) would be impaired, and sensory deficits in the face would occur on the same side as those of the trunk and extremities. Moreover, miosis is usually absent because the Edinger-Westphal nucleus and/or its efferent parasympathetic fibers would also be damaged, and features such as hoarseness and diminished gag reflex would not occur. Instead, patients would present with hemiparesis and hemianopia with macular sparing, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Left: Transverse section at the level of the superior colliculi
The mesencephalon contains the tectum (yellow), the tegmentum (green), and the crus cerebri (blue).

Right: Transverse section
Important functional structures are depicted.

C) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the paramedian branches in the cranial segment of the anterior spinal artery causes medial medullary syndrome (MMS), which manifests with unilateral sensory deficits of the trunk and extremities, which are seen here. However, proprioception, vibration, and fine touch are impaired (due to medial lemniscus damage) instead of temperature and pain sensations. Sensory loss in the face, hoarseness, diminished gag reflex, nystagmus, and Horner syndrome would not be expected. Instead, patients with MMS have inferior alternating hemiplegia (ipsilateral paralysis of the tongue due to hypoglossal nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis due to corticospinal tract damage), which is not seen here.

Occlusion of the anterior spinal artery below the level of the medulla causes anterior spinal cord syndrome, which manifests with loss of pain and temperature sensations in the trunk and extremities (due to lateral spinothalamic tract damage) but these sensory deficits would be present bilaterally rather than unilaterally. In addition, quadriplegia or paraplegia would also be present, and features of brain stem lesions (e.g., nystagmus, hoarseness, diminished gag reflex, Horner syndrome, loss of sensations in the face) would not be expected.
Image Description:

Dorsal view of the brainstem

D) CORRECT:

The lateral medulla is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) and the lateral pons by the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). Both infarction of the lateral medulla (lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome) and lateral pons (lateral pontine syndrome) manifest with loss of pain and temperature sensations in one half of the face and the contralateral trunk and extremities, as well as vestibulocerebellar symptoms (e.g., nystagmus, vertigo, ataxia) and unilateral Horner syndrome. The two conditions can be differentiated based on the presence or absence of certain cranial nerve palsies. Lateral medullary syndrome also manifests with features of CN IX and CN X palsies as a result of nucleus ambiguus infarction, whereas lateral pontine syndrome manifests with features of cochlear nucleus infarction and CN VII palsy because of facial nucleus infarction.

Blood is supplied to the brainstem through the following vessels: anterior spinal artery (medial medulla), posterior inferior cerebellar artery (lateral medulla), basilar artery (medial pons), anterior inferior cerebellar artery (lateral pons), superior cerebellar artery (caudal midbrain), posterior cerebral artery (rostral midbrain).
Image Description:

Wallenberg syndrome results from occlusion of either the vertebral artery or its branch, the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). Occlusion leads to lateral medullary infarction, which can affect multiple brainstem areas in the following ways:

– Lateral spinothalamic tract (purple): contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk and limbs
– Trigeminal nucleus (purple): ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face
– Vestibular nucleus (red): vertigo with falling to the affected side and nystagmus to the opposite side
– Inferior cerebellar peduncle (dark blue): ataxia and dysmetria
– Nucleus ambiguus (green): dysphagia, hoarseness, and a decreased gag reflex
– Sympathetic fibers (light blue): Horner syndrome

Nucleus ambiguus injury and damage to sympathetic fibers can both cause persistent hiccups.

E) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of an anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) causes lateral pontine syndrome, which manifests with nystagmus, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and loss of pain and temperature sensation in the ipsilateral face and contralateral trunk and extremities, all of which is seen here. However, patients with this syndrome also have facial asymmetry (due to CN VII palsy) and unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (due to cochlear nucleus palsy), which are not seen here. In addition, features of CN IX or CN X palsy (hoarseness, diminished gag reflex) would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Isolated occlusion of a posterior communicating artery (PCOM) typically does not cause stroke. However, a stroke can occur if the ipsilateral internal carotid artery is also occluded because the PCOM provides collateral blood flow from the posterior cerebral artery to the vascular territory of the internal carotid artery. Occlusion of the internal carotid artery would cause a cortical stroke and manifest with cortical deficits such as hemispatial neglect, aphasia, gaze preference, and urinary incontinence, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

The circle of Willis is depicted in light red with the main arteries of the brain in dark red.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of damage to the nucleus ambiguus (hoarseness and diminished gag reflex), spinal trigeminal nucleus (loss of pain and temperature sensations in the face ipsilaterally), spinothalamic tract (loss of pain and temperature sensations in the contralateral trunk and extremities), vestibular nucleus (nystagmus), and hypothalamospinal tract (ipsilateral ptosis and miosis). This constellation of features suggests that the infarction is located in the lateral medulla.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of left-sided body weakness and difficulty speaking. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 151/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows deviation of the tongue to the right, left-sided hemiparesis, and decreased proprioception on the left side of the body. Sensation to pinprick and temperature is intact. This patient's condition is most likely caused by occlusion of which of the following labeled vessels in the schematic overview of the arterial supply to the brain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the right middle cerebral artery (MCA), which supplies a large part of the lateral surface of the right (typically nondominant) cerebral cortex. Occlusion of this artery can cause left-sided neurological deficits, primarily of the face and upper limbs, such as weakness (due to primary motor cortex infarction), sensory loss (due to primary sensory cortex infarction), and difficulty speaking (due to labial dysarthria caused by upper motor neuron CN VII palsy). However, all types of sensations, not just proprioception, would be impaired and deviation of the tongue would not be expected. Instead, patients typically present with left homonymous hemianopia (due to infarction of the optic radiations) and left hemineglect (due to infarction of the nondominant frontal and parietal lobes).
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

B) INCORRECT:

This is the right posterior cerebral artery (PCA), which supplies the rostral midbrain, thalamus, occipital lobe, and inferomedial temporal lobe ipsilaterally. Occlusion of this artery can cause left-sided sensory loss (due to infarction of the right ventral posterolateral nucleus or the right ascending sensory tracts) and left-sided hemiparesis (due to infarction of the right corticospinal tracts), which are seen here. However, in PCA occlusion, all types of sensations (not just proprioception) are impaired and features such as difficulty speaking and deviation of the tongue would not be expected. Instead, left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, memory deficits, and vertigo would be expected.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

C) CORRECT:

This artery, which is formed by the union of branches from the vertebral artery and located in the midline on the ventral surface of the medulla and spinal cord, is the anterior spinal artery. Occlusion of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery and/or vertebral artery can lead to medial medullary syndrome, which is caused by infarction of the corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal nucleus, as seen here. This patient's history of coronary heart disease, hypertension, and smoking history suggests a thrombotic stroke, which is caused by plaque rupture in arteriosclerotic arteries. After the exclusion of bleeding as a cause, treatment will most likely consist of reperfusion therapy, supportive care, and prevention of post-stroke complications.

Occlusion of the anterior spinal artery below the level of the medulla causes anterior spinal cord syndrome, which manifests with quadriplegia or paraplegia and bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensations in the trunk and extremities.
Image Description:

Caudal view

The circle of Willis is formed around the pituitary stalk by the following paired arteries:
- Anterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the internal carotids)
- Internal carotid arteries (proximal to the origin of the middle cerebral arteries)
- Posterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the vertebral arteries)

The anterior communicating artery (ventral to the optic chiasm) connects the anterior cerebral arteries.

The posterior communicating artery (a branch of internal carotid artery; lies on the lateral aspect of the pituitary stalk) connects the internal carotid artery and the posterior cerebral artery.

The basilar artery, formed by the fusion of the two vertebral arteries, lies in the midline groove of the dorsal aspect of the pons. Pontine and labyrinthine branches arise from the basilar artery.

The anterior spinal artery, formed by the fusion of the branches of the vertebral artery, lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord.

D) INCORRECT:

This is the left superior cerebellar artery, which supplies the superior cerebellar peduncle, anterior cerebellar lobe, and part of the lateral tegmentum ipsilaterally. Occlusion of this artery can result in difficulty speaking (due to ataxic dysarthria), and, occasionally, sensory deficits, which are seen here. However, sensory loss would occur on the right side (due to left spinothalamic tract infarction) and involve pain and temperature modalities rather than proprioception. In addition, deviation of the tongue and hemiparesis are not consistent with a superior cerebellar artery infarct. Instead, cerebellar signs (e.g., vertigo, nystagmus, ataxic gait, dysmetria) and Horner syndrome would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

This is the basilar artery, which supplies the ventromedial parts of the midbrain, pons, and rostral medulla via its paramedian and circumferential branches. The clinical features of basilar artery occlusion vary depending on the site at which the basilar artery is occluded. The most severe manifestation is locked-in syndrome, which manifests as quadriplegia and bulbar palsy with preserved consciousness, blinking, and vertical eye movements. The presence of hypoglossal nerve palsy in this patient means that the infarct can be localized to the medial part of the caudal medulla, which receives blood from a different vessel.

F) INCORRECT:

This is the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). The AICA supplies structures located in the lateral pons such as CN VII nucleus, vestibular nucleus, spinothalamic tract, spinal trigeminal nucleus, hypothalamospinal tract, and middle and inferior cerebellar peduncles. Occlusion of the AICA causes features of lateral pontine syndrome such as difficulty speaking (due to labial dysarthria) and sensory deficits, which are seen here. However, sensory loss would involve pain and temperature modalities rather than proprioception and, in patients with left AICA occlusion, sensory deficits would occur on the right side. In addition, hemiparesis and deviation of the tongue would not be expected. Instead, Horner syndrome, vertigo, and ataxia would be seen.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of infarction in the right corticospinal tract (left-sided hemiparesis), right medial lemniscus (left-sided loss of proprioception), and right hypoglossal nucleus (deviation of the tongue to the right and difficulty speaking due to dysarthria).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife for the evaluation of a suspected stroke. He has a history of chronic hypertension. The patient's wife reports that he is right-handed. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows an acute cerebral infarction. A photograph of a transverse section of a normal brain is shown; the area that is affected by the infarction is indicated by the arrow. This patient most likely presented with which of the following findings on physical examination?

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the left arm
Hemianopia of the right visual field

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Weakness of the right leg is the most likely physical finding of a lacunar infarction of the posterior limb of the left internal capsule, which is located between the lentiform nucleus (basal ganglia) and thalamus and contains the anterior corticospinal tract, lateral corticospinal tract, and thalamocortical tract. Pure motor hemiparesis, the most common type of lacunar stroke, is caused by an isolated infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule. Affected individuals present with contralateral hemiparesis (due to corticospinal tract damage) in the absence of cortical signs (e.g., aphasia, visual field abnormalities). Chronic hypertension, as seen in this patient, is a risk factor for microatheroma formation and lipohyalinosis in the poorly-collateralized small penetrating arteries of the brain (e.g., lenticulostriate arteries), which can result in lacunar stroke.

Other parts of the internal capsule include the anterior limb, which contains the thalamocortical tract, and the genu, which contains the corticobulbar tract.
Image Description:

Transverse section; cranial view

B) INCORRECT:

Hemineglect is most commonly caused by a lesion affecting the nondominant parietal cortex (which is typically the right parietal cortex in right-handed individuals). Consequently, right-handed individuals typically only present with hemineglect of the left side. Moreover, this patient has an infarct of a deep brain structure in the left hemisphere, not the right parietal cortex.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemiballismus is most commonly caused by a lacunar stroke involving the contralateral subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nuclei are a pair of grey matter structures located caudal to the thalamus, cranial to the substantia nigra (part of the midbrain), and medial to the internal capsule. The transverse section shown here is taken at the level of the thalamus; the subthalamic nuclei are not visible in this section.

D) INCORRECT:

An infarct of the internal capsule can manifest with hemifacial paralysis as a result of damage to the corticobulbar tracts that supply the facial motor nuclei. However, a left-sided internal capsule infarct, as described here, would cause paralysis of the right rather than left lower facial muscles because the lower division of the facial nucleus receives upper motor neuron innervation from the contralateral corticobulbar tract. Moreover, corticobulbar tracts travel within the genu (flexure) of the internal capsule, whereas the arrow is pointing at the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

E) INCORRECT:

An infarct involving the posterior limb of the internal capsule may manifest with a loss of arm sensation as a result of damage to the thalamocortical tract (which conveys somatosensory information from the contralateral body to the cortex). However, an infarct in the left internal capsule, as depicted in the photograph, would cause loss of sensation of the right arm rather than the left.
Image Description:

Left image: the dorsal column (gracile fasciculus and cuneate fasciculus) carries information of fine touch, vibration, pressure, and proprioception (gracile fasciculus: primarily from the lower half of the body; cuneate fasciculus: primarily from the upper half of the body).

Right side: the anterolateral column (anterior spinothalamic tract and lateral spinothalamic tract) carries information of crude touch, pressure, pain, and temperature.
1) Anterior spinothalamic tract: The first neuron is located within the spinal ganglia. Axons from the first neuron split and ascend or descend several segments (a). Having reached another segment, they synapse to the second neuron in the posterior horn of the spinal cord, and the axons decussate to the contralateral side of the spinal cord within the anterior white commissure (b). Further ascend in the anterior spinothalamic tract (c, d). Synapse to the 3rd neuron in the thalamus (e).
2) Lateral spinothalamic tract: The first neuron is located within the spinal ganglia. Synapse to the 2nd neuron in the gray matter on the same segment. The axon of the 2nd neuron decussates to the contralateral side of the spinal cord within the anterior white commissure (a). Ascend in the lateral spinothalamic tract (b, c, d). Synapse to the 3rd neuron in the thalamus (e).

Both pathways end in the somatosensory cortex and transmit sensory information.

F) INCORRECT:

Hemianopia of the right visual field (i.e., right homonymous hemianopia) is most commonly caused by a post-chiasmal cortical lesion within the contralateral optic tract, optic radiation, or visual cortex (in the occipital lobe). Parts of the optic radiations and occipital lobes are seen on this transverse brain slice, but these structures are located in the posterior region of the slice. The arrow in the image points to a different structure.
Image Description:

The left optic radiation is indicated by an arrow.
questions.hint: This arrow points at the posterior limb of the left internal capsule.

questions.text: Two days after being admitted for an ischemic stroke of the left middle cerebral artery, a 74-year-old woman is evaluated for worsening confusion. She received intravenous alteplase therapy and was admitted to the intensive care unit. Twenty-four hours after being admitted, the patient started antiplatelet therapy; she was already able to speak in full sentences and had slightly improved muscle function. While being evaluated by the physical therapist this morning, the patient was confused. Her pulse is 72/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mm Hg. She does not respond to verbal commands but withdraws appropriately to painful stimuli. Neurologic examination shows equal and reactive pupils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hemorrhagic transformation (HT) is a common complication of ischemic stroke and typically manifests with neurologic deterioration (e.g., new confusion, worsening neurological deficits) within 24–48 hours of the inciting ischemic event. The risk of hemorrhagic transformation is significantly increased in patients who have received thrombolytic medications (e.g., alteplase), antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel), and/or thrombosis prophylaxis (e.g., heparin, enoxaparin). Other risk factors for HT include hyperglycemia, hypertension, advanced age, delayed initiation of reperfusion therapy, and large infarct size. Measures that can reduce the rate of HT include neuroprotective measures (e.g., tight blood pressure and glycemic control, targeted temperature management) and careful preselection of patients eligible for thrombolytic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral vasospasm is a complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which typically occurs 4–14 days after the inciting event and would cause neurologic deterioration. Cerebral vasospasm is not, however, a complication of ischemic stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Recurrent ischemic stroke can manifest with neurologic deterioration after a period of stabilization or improvement after ischemic injury. However, this patient has received thrombolytic therapy (alteplase) and has already been started on antiplatelet therapy, both of which significantly reduce the likelihood of recurrent ischemic stroke. A different complication of ischemic stroke is more likely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Uncal herniation can manifest with neurologic deterioration but would also cause pupillary changes (e.g., ipsilateral mydriasis) and signs of cardiorespiratory compromise (e.g., bradycardia, apnea), none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: This condition occurs as a result of reperfusion injury, which leads to endothelial damage and disruption of the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman with a history of heavy cocaine use, alcohol use disorder, and coronary artery disease reports having vivid dreams, heart palpitations, hypersomnia, and low mood for the past week, as well as weakness in her right arm and leg. She is slurring her words, appears disheveled, and smells of alcohol. She seems to be responding to internal stimuli and is engaged in a conversation with herself — a new symptom for her. She has poor dentition but no other medical problems. She takes no medications.
On examination, her heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. She has difficulty moving her right upper and lower extremities. Her muscle strength is 5 out of 5 in the left upper and left lower extremities, 3 out of 5 in the right upper extremity, and 4 out of 5 in the right lower extremity. Her deep-tendon reflexes are increased on the right, and a Babinski sign is present at the right toe.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Comprehensive urine and serum drug testing
Measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although carotid ultrasound could be part of the evaluation once stroke has been established, head imaging is the first step to confirm a stroke and exclude other lesions in the brain that could be responsible for this presentation (such as abscess or hemorrhage).

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s psychiatric symptoms (low mood, thought disorder, and hypersomnia) are all characteristic of cocaine withdrawal. However, cocaine withdrawal is rarely medically serious and should not produce focal neurologic findings. Unilateral weakness, hyperreflexia and a Babinski sign cannot be explained by alcohol intoxication or cocaine withdrawal and are symptoms of stroke. Over time, cocaine use substantially increases the risk for stroke, myocardial infarction, and arrhythmia. Concurrent use of cocaine and alcohol leads to production of the metabolite cocaethylene, which also increases cardiovascular risk. In this scenario, the patient’s neurologic symptoms require the most immediate attention, and CT is the best choice for urgent imaging of suspected stroke.

Key learning point: Unilateral weakness in a patient intoxicated with cocaine and alcohol should prompt an evaluation for the diagnosis of stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Polysubstance use should eventually be addressed in a patient withdrawing from cocaine. However, this patient’s presentation is not typical of a toxidrome, and laboratory tests for urine and serum cocaine levels are not as urgent at this time as evaluating for a stroke.

D) INCORRECT:

Electrocardiography and measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level may be useful for further evaluation but are less urgently required than CT.

E) INCORRECT:

Electrocardiography and measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level may be useful for further evaluation but are less urgently required than CT.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old man presents one day after having speech arrest, facial weakness and numbness, and weakness of the left arm. The episode lasted approximately 60 minutes and then resolved. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.
His blood pressure is 173/98 mm Hg, and his pulse is 75 beats per minute. He has diminished pulses in the distal extremities. His neurologic examination is unremarkable. There are no carotid bruits or cardiac murmurs.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s evaluation?

choices.text: MRI and MR angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography (EEG) would be indicated if the patient was presenting after a recent seizure. However, the episode described is less likely to be a seizure given the predominately negative symptoms (weakness and aphasia) and long duration.

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid Doppler ultrasonography can identify carotid stenosis that might explain the transient ischemic attack (TIA). However, neuroimaging is the first step in the workup of suspected stroke or TIA, and the lack of a carotid bruit on examination makes the carotid ultrasonography lower yield.

C) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography can be used to evaluate for an embolic source of transient ischemic attack (TIA), but it is a lower priority than cerebral imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest radiography is not likely to be immediately helpful in evaluating a patient with a new transient ischemic attack (TIA).

E) CORRECT:

In patients with transient ischemic attack (TIA), risk factors for stroke include age ≥60 years, systolic blood pressure ≥140 mm Hg, unilateral weakness, and a TIA duration of at least one hour. Hence, this patient’s risk for stroke is high, approximately 8% within 2 days after the attack. Further evaluation for remediable causes of stroke is appropriate.

This patient should receive brain imaging with either MRI or CT. MRI is the diagnostic modality of choice as it has the greatest sensitivity for small areas of infarction, which might be seen in patients with TIA, even if symptoms resolve. CT is not as sensitive for small infarcts but is more widely available than MRI. This patient should also undergo imaging of the blood vessels (angiography). Vessel imaging provides additional information about intracranial stenosis or carotid stenosis and thereby allows for early identification of patients who might benefit from urgent carotid endarterectomy. The vessels are usually imaged using CT or MR angiography, which is performed at the same time and using the same modality as the brain imaging.

Key learning point: The most appropriate type of initial imaging for a patient with a transient ischemic attack is MR or CT angiography of the head and neck.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 65 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: African-American, self-identified
Site of Care: clinic
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have burning pain on the right side of my body, even at the lightest touch.”
History of Present Illness:


1-month history of right-sided burning pain and intermittent paresthesia in the extremities
pain exacerbated by touch and movement; severity 9/10; refractory to acetaminophen and ibuprofen

3-month history of memory disturbances, sleep disturbances, and fatigue

Past Medical History:

type 2 diabetes mellitus
hypertension
hyperlipidemia
herpes zoster 1 year ago

ischemic stroke 4 months ago


Medications:

amlodipine
lisinopril
aspirin
metformin
glimepiride
atorvastatin
codeine
gabapentin

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
penicillin
Family History:

father: deceased at age 65 from myocardial infarction
mother: deceased at age 71 from stroke

Psychosocial History:

lives alone
retired taxi driver
has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 45 years


Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37.4°C(99.3°F)
80/min
16/min
145/85 mm Hg
-
176 cm(5 ft 9 in)
95 kg(209 lb)
30.9 kg/m2




Appearance: fully oriented, uncomfortable, sitting in a chair
Skin: no rashes
Extremities: dorsalis pedis, radial and femoral pulses intact bilaterally; no edema or tenderness
Neurologic: no focal neurologic deficits in the left upper and lower extremities; 3/5 muscle strength with increased muscle tone and hyperreflexia in the right upper and lower extremities; hyperesthesia, impaired temperature sensation, and allodynia noted on the right side


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thalamic pain syndrome (central poststroke pain; Dejerine-Roussy syndrome) commonly follows posterior cerebral artery stroke, which typically involves the thalamogeniculate arteries or the posterior choroidal arteries and leads to damage in the ventral posterolateral nucleus. Characteristic symptoms are initial paresthesia followed by neuropathic pain, allodynia, and dysesthesia. These symptoms typically occur on the contralateral side if the trunk and extremities are affected and in the hemifacial region ipsilateral to the stroke. Management of thalamic pain syndrome involves a multidisciplinary approach that integrates pharmacological, physical, and psychological interventions, along with comorbidity management and patient education. Invasive treatment (e.g., deep brain stimulation) may be considered if the pain is refractory to conservative management.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibromyalgia manifests with diffuse musculoskeletal pain, which is commonly neuropathic and often accompanies paresthesia, memory disturbances, and fatigue. However, pain at tender points across the body is expected rather than allodynic hemisensory pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is characterized by pain that is excessive in duration or severity in proportion to the inciting event. The pain is often accompanied by allodynia and hyperesthesia. However, CRPS typically follows limb trauma, and sudomotor or vasomotor features are expected, such as hypothermia/hyperthermia, hypopigmentation/hyperpigmentation, and hypohidrosis/hyperhidrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy manifests with dysesthesia and may also lead to paresthesia, allodynia, and muscle weakness. However, diabetic neuropathy typically consists of distal symmetrical sensory loss (stocking-glove distribution) with a proximal progression rather than a hemisensory distribution.

E) INCORRECT:

Postherpetic neuralgia is characterized by allodynia, paresthesia, and dysesthesia following herpes zoster (shingles). However, pain typically follows the dermatomal distribution of the rash rather than a hemisensory distribution.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is typically the first-line imaging modality for patients with symptomatic CAS (e.g., TIA, amaurosis fugax, ischemic stroke). Some guidelines also recommend ultrasonography of the neck to screen for CAS in asymptomatic patients with a carotid bruit and multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In patients with CAS, ultrasonography shows a focally-increased velocity of blood flow. Duplex ultrasonography is an inexpensive, noninvasive test with high specificity and sensitivity for the detection of CAS. It can also quantify the degree of stenosis.

Antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, blood pressure control, and lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation, weight control, regular exercise) are the mainstays of treatment in CAS. Carotid revascularization (typically with carotid endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease and severe stenosis (≥ 70%).

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to identify cardiogenic sources of emboli in patients with symptomatic ischemic neurological disease (e.g., TIA) without a clear intracranial or extracranial vascular etiology. However, this patient's physical exam revealed a carotid bruit that is likely secondary to CAS. Echocardiography would not be the next best step for evaluating CAS.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with CAS, anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are not used for stroke prevention. Instead, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) are used. Warfarin is used for stroke prevention only in patients with certain risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves).

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography and MR angiography are not first-line imaging modalities in the workup of CAS, but they can be used to confirm the diagnosis if the first-line modality shows findings consistent with the condition or yields inconclusive results (e.g., due to significant carotid artery calcification). Angiography also plays a role in preoperative risk stratification and intervention planning.

E) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography of the neck, which requires arterial catheterization, used to be the preferred test for evaluating CAS but it has been replaced by other modalities because it is an invasive and costly procedure that carries a ∼ 4% risk of iatrogenic neurological complications (e.g., stroke). Although it may have some utility in select patient groups (e.g., if the initial imaging modalities reveal discordant results or additional anatomic detail is needed), it would not be used as a first-line diagnostic test.
Image Description:

MR angiography (right carotid artery)

There is severe stenosis (hatched green overlay) of the proximal internal carotid artery.

1: superior thyroid artery; 2: lingual artery; 3: facial artery
questions.hint: This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.

questions.text: One day after undergoing left carotid endarterectomy, a 63-year-old man has a severe headache that he describes as 9 out of 10 in intensity. He had 80% stenosis in the left carotid artery and received heparin prior to the surgery. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and aspirin. His blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. There is a right facial droop, weakness of the right upper and lower extremities, and right-sided hyperreflexia. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis is a risk factor for embolic (through carotid plaque emboli) and thrombotic (through carotid plaque thrombosis) ischemic stroke. Carotid stroke and intracerebral hemorrhage also share multiple risk factors. However, patients with early signs of ischemic stroke on noncontrast CT typically have hypodense parenchyma and loss of grey-white matter differentiation; this patient has a hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema, which indicates ICH.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A hypodense occipital infarct (green) in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery is accompanied by a loss of normal gray-white matter differentiation. The density of the lesion is greater than that of CSF. There is no mass effect or hemorrhage. Choroid plexus calcifications in the lateral ventricles are physiologic.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation, theoretically predisposing patients to bleeding such as intracerebral hemorrhage. However, aspirin therapy only minimally increases the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage, if at all.

C) INCORRECT:

The risk of intracerebral hemorrhage is directly correlated with the degree of anticoagulation (e.g., by heparin). However, anticoagulation is not the strongest risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage.

D) CORRECT:

Arterial hypertension is the single most important predisposing factor for atraumatic intracerebral hemorrhage. Chronic hypertension results in lipohyalinosis of the arterial walls, leading to microaneurysm formation and elevated risk of rupture. Acute hypertension then leads to rupture of the weakened vessels, which likely was the mechanism of rupture in this patient.

Management of intracerebral hemorrhage depends on the intracranial pressure (ICP) of the patient. If ICP is normal, blood pressure should be decreased to < 160 mm Hg through labetalol or nicardipine administration. If intracranial hypertension is suspected (as is likely in this patient, given his altered mental status), blood pressure should be lowered more cautiously, as cerebral perfusion must be maintained. Finally, if herniation is suspected (e.g., uncal herniation), emergency craniotomy is required.
Image Description:

Hemorrhage in the region of the left basal ganglia causing a midline shift to the right

The basal ganglia are supplied by the lenticulostriate arteries, which arise from the middle cerebral artery. Hemorrhage from a lenticulostriate artery (e.g., due to poorly controlled hypertension or rupture of a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm) leads to a basal ganglia hemorrhage.

E) INCORRECT:

Smoking does increase the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage in a dose-response relationship. The mechanism is likely multifactorial and includes both increased blood pressure and arterial wall damage associated with smoking. However, it is not the strongest risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage.
questions.hint: This patient has clinical features of a stroke (e.g., facial droop, right-sided hemiparesis, hyperreflexia, headache) and a CT scan of the head that shows intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH; hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema) in the left hemisphere.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after his wife noticed that the right side of his face was drooping during breakfast. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. He has an implanted insulin pump for blood sugar control. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Visual field testing shows right-sided homonymous hemianopia. Neurologic examination shows a right facial droop. Muscle strength and sensation are decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Speech is dysarthric. There is a bruit on the left side of the neck. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Noncontrast CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is an appropriate diagnostic modality in the initial work-up of suspected stroke. However, this patient has an implanted insulin pump, which could be adversely affected by the MRI scanner.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) may be used in the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which typically manifests with a thunderclap headache that rapidly progresses to nausea, vomiting, cardiovascular dysfunction, coma, and then death. SAH can cause stroke, but as this patient lacks the characteristic history of sudden-onset, severe headache that is present in almost all patients with SAH, this diagnosis is less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is used to identify carotid stenosis, for which this patient is at high risk (as suggested by carotid bruit and likely thromboembolic stroke), but the diagnosis and treatment of this patient's suspected stroke takes priority over confirming carotid stenosis; confirmation of carotid stenosis would not affect acute stroke management. Duplex ultrasonography would likely be performed later on in management, once the acute phase of the stroke has been managed.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral angiography (i.e., CTA or MRA) can be used in the diagnosis of stroke and to facilitate in-situ treatment (i.e., mechanical thrombectomy). However, because angiography uses intravasal contrast, hemorrhage should be excluded first. Therefore, a different step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) CORRECT:

An emergency, noncontrast CT scan of the head is the preferred imaging technique to rule out intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in patients with suspected stroke and should be carried out before other management (e.g., thrombolysis). Additionally, a CT scan may detect signs of ischemia (e.g., hypoattenuation or large clots in a blood vessel). CT scans are fast and can significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality of stroke. Although MRI can be used as an alternative for diagnosis, it is inappropriate in this patient because it could adversely affect his implanted insulin pump. If initial imaging is inconclusive but clinical suspicion for ICH is high (e.g., thunderclap headache), a lumbar puncture may be performed to evaluate for signs of the condition (e.g., erythrocytes) in the cerebrospinal fluid.

This patient has several risk factors for stroke (i.e., diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and smoking), and the carotid bruit suggests a thromboembolic ischemic stroke. This patient's presentation (right-sided facial droop, sensory and motor deficit in the right upper and lower extremities, right-sided homonymous hemianopia, dysarthria) is consistent with ischemia in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery.

Key learning point: In suspected acute stroke, a noncontrast CT scan of the head is the initial diagnostic test to rapidly exclude intracerebral hemorrhage before considering thrombolytic therapy.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
BP: blood pressure
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
DW-MRI: diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging
ECG: electrocardiogram
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
MRI: magnetic resonance imaging
NIHSS: National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale
POC: point-of-care
questions.hint: Acute onset of focal neurologic symptoms should raise concern for stroke, which is a neurologic emergency that requires fast workup.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of his left leg for the past hour. He was unable to get out of bed that morning. His pants are soaked with urine. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the left lower extremity. Sensation is decreased in the left lower extremity. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time and has a flat affect. When asked to count backwards from 20, he stops after counting to 17. When asked to name 10 words beginning with the letter “d,” he stops after naming two words. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) may manifest with urinary incontinence and behavioral changes including a flattened affect and abulia. However, this condition is a gradually progressive disease, unlike the acute presentation in this patient. Although patients with NPH may have a feeling of weakness and numbness, true sensory deficits or lower limb weakness severe enough to impair movement are not typically seen. Instead, gait abnormalities (typically a shuffling, wide-based gait) are usually the earliest sign.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

B) INCORRECT:

A large infarct in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) can cause abulia and sensory and motor neurologic deficits on the left side of the body. However, neurologic deficits are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk than in the lower limb. Also, a patient with a massive right MCA stroke would present with left hemineglect (if the right hemisphere is nondominant) or aphasia (if the right hemisphere is dominant).

C) CORRECT:

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial part of the frontal lobe and parietal lobe. These areas provide motor and sensory innervation of the lower extremities as well as control of micturition. Occlusion of the postcommunal segment (distal to the circle of Willis) of the right ACA typically results in upper motor neuron weakness manifesting with a contralateral positive Babinski sign, sensory deficits of the contralateral lower limb, and urinary incontinence. Signs of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia), as well as aphasia and limb apraxia, may also be present.
