Key learning point: Anterior cerebral artery occlusion causes contralateral lower extremity weakness and sensory loss, urinary incontinence, and frontal lobe signs such as abulia and impaired executive function.

D) INCORRECT:

A right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in left homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, other features such as prosopagnosia (in individuals where the right hemisphere is the nondominant one) would also be expected.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive encephalopathy is a hypertensive emergency that occurs in patients with a mean arterial pressure >180 mm Hg and can cause neurologic deficits and nonlocalizing signs of cerebral edema, such as severe headache, nausea, and/or vomiting. Furthermore, hypertensive encephalopathy typically has an insidious onset, in contrast to the acute onset in this patient. Other features such as findings of grade IV hypertensive retinopathy on fundoscopy (flame-shaped hemorrhage, papilledema, and/or cotton wool spots) would also be present.
questions.hint: This patient has sudden-onset neurologic symptoms. An inability to complete goal-directed tests such as counting backward from 20 or naming words starting with the letter “d”, a flat affect indicates abulia, which is usually the result of damage to the frontal lobe.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after the sudden onset of speech difficulties and right-sided arm and leg weakness. Examination shows paralysis and hypoesthesia on the right side, positive Babinski sign on the right, and slurred speech. A CT scan of the head shows a hyperdensity in the left middle cerebral artery and no evidence of intracranial bleeding. The patient's symptoms improve rapidly after pharmacotherapy is initiated and his weakness completely resolves. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rivaroxaban, a direct factor Xa inhibitor, is used for the prevention of ischemic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and the treatment of venous thromboembolism, to name a few indications. Despite its prophylactic value, it has no role in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke. Hence, it is unlikely to be given to this patient with an acute ischemic stroke.

B) CORRECT:

Alteplase, a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, is the mainstay of treatment to salvage ischemic tissue in acute ischemic stroke. This drug converts plasminogen to plasmin, which dissolves clots by degrading fibrin. Alteplase is typically administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset but can be used later under specialist guidance. Important contradictions include acute intracranial hemorrhage, recent surgery, severe uncontrolled hypertension, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy.

Key learning point: Alteplase, a tissue plasminogen activator, is the first-line thrombolytic therapy for acute ischemic stroke when given within 4.5 hours of symptom onset and in the absence of contraindications.

C) INCORRECT:

Heparin is used for the acute treatment of several conditions such as venous thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism, and STEMI. It activates antithrombin III in a manner that inhibits both thrombin and factor X. Early use of heparin in acute ischemic stroke has been associated with higher mortality and worse outcomes as compared to other anticoagulants.

D) INCORRECT:

Prasugrel, a platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor, is given to patients with acute coronary syndrome and for those undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (to prevent coronary stent thrombosis). The drug inhibits platelet aggregation by preventing the expression of Gp IIb/IIIa receptors on the platelet surface. Prasugrel is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or TIA because of the increased risk of significant or fatal bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist used for the prophylaxis of ischemic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, and as treatment for patients with venous thromboembolism. It inhibits hepatic epoxide reductase, thereby blocking synthesis (recycling) of the active, reduced form of vit. K. Without reduced vit. K, γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues cannot occur, which reduces the production of active coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as anticoagulatory proteins C and S. Because this drug takes days to exert and remove its clinically significant anticoagulatory effect, it is primarily used for chronic anticoagulation and has no use in the acute setting.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms in combination with the CT results (hyperdense occluded vessel) indicate an ischemic stroke caused by an obstructive lesion in the left middle cerebral artery. The drug administered can also be used to treat patients with early myocardial infarctions or unstable patients with a pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty speaking that began abruptly one hour ago. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences, and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries
Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery
Rupture of left posterior cerebral artery malformation
Dissection of the left vertebral artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which manifests with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries that supply the left posterior limb of the internal capsule can result in right-sided weakness, as seen in this patient. However, Broca aphasia localizes to the inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

C) CORRECT:

Broca aphasia is caused by damage of the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (typically left) hemisphere. This patient additionally has right facial droop, right-sided muscle weakness, and right-sided pronator drift downwards, suggesting an upper motor neuron lesion in the left motor cortex. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the inferior frontal gyrus, as well as the motor cortex. This patient has several risk factors for arteriosclerosis and, therefore, ischemic stroke (hypertension, age > 65 years, diabetes mellitus), making occlusion of the left MCA the most likely cause of his focal neurologic deficits.

Ischemic strokes do not typically cause headaches, whereas hemorrhagic strokes usually manifest with severe headaches.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

D) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage into the left posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a left posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause right-sided hemiparesis, as seen in this patient. However, rupture of this artery would also cause right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present here. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

E) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the left vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits that are consistent with stroke. Telegraphic speech (as evidenced by the use of short, simple sentences), intact comprehension (as evidenced by the ability to follow commands), and impaired repetition of word sequences are consistent with Broca aphasia. The presence of this type of language deficit helps localize the damage to a specific region of the cortex.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset right arm weakness and drooping of the right side of his face that began 20 minutes ago. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and is taking low-dose aspirin. He has no known allergies or recent surgeries. He is alert but has slurred speech. Physical examination reveals normal deep tendon reflexes and no meningeal signs.


Heart rate
90/min


Blood pressure
185/98 mm Hg


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Non-contrast CT scan of the head
Rapidly lower blood pressure with intravenous agents

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is used for acute ischemic stroke within a specific time window, but only after confirming the absence of intracranial hemorrhage via neuroimaging. Administering tPA without imaging could be dangerous, especially with elevated blood pressure, which increases the risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous heparin is not recommended for initial management of acute ischemic stroke without confirming the absence of hemorrhage. Heparin use in acute stroke has not shown benefit in reducing disability and carries a risk of hemorrhagic transformation, especially without prior imaging.

C) CORRECT:

The sudden onset of unilateral weakness and facial drooping in a patient with vascular risk factors suggests a cerebrovascular event. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is crucial to differentiate between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke, as treatment strategies differ significantly. Rapid imaging is essential to determine eligibility for time-sensitive interventions, such as thrombolysis, making non-contrast head CT the most appropriate initial diagnostic step.

Key learning point: In the acute setting of suspected stroke, a non-contrast brain CT scan is the first step to differentiate between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke before initiating treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

In acute ischemic stroke, elevated blood pressure may help maintain cerebral perfusion. Rapidly lowering blood pressure can reduce perfusion to ischemic areas, worsening injury. Blood pressure management is guided by specific thresholds, and aggressive reduction is reserved for confirmed hemorrhagic stroke or hypertensive emergencies.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after being found on the bathroom floor. He has well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He is awake and alert but has difficulty standing or walking. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the left arm, 1/5 in the left leg, and reduced proprioception in the left lower extremity. Facial muscles are intact. Motor and sensory function in the right extremities are normal. No aphasia or visual field deficits are noted.
Which arterial territory is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The right middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cerebral hemisphere, affecting motor and sensory functions in the face and arm. An infarct here would typically cause facial weakness and more pronounced arm deficits. The patient's predominant lower extremity weakness and intact facial muscles suggest involvement of a territory primarily controlling leg function, not the MCA.

B) INCORRECT:

The left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the medial frontal and parietal cortex, affecting the contralateral lower extremity. However, the patient's left-sided deficits indicate a right hemisphere lesion. An infarct in the left ACA would affect the right leg, not the left, making a right ACA lesion more consistent with the observed symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

The right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe, often causing visual deficits like contralateral homonymous hemianopia. The patient's motor weakness and reduced proprioception in the left leg, without visual deficits, suggest involvement of the medial frontal and parietal lobes, supplied by the anterior cerebral artery, not the PCA.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including marked weakness and reduced proprioception in the left leg with relatively preserved upper extremity and facial function, suggest involvement of the right anterior cerebral artery (ACA). The ACA supplies the medial frontal and parietal lobes, where the motor and sensory cortices for the lower limb are located. This vascular territory's involvement typically results in pronounced deficits in the contralateral leg, as seen in this patient. The motor homunculus organization supports this, as the ACA territory primarily affects the lower extremity, unlike the middle cerebral artery, which affects the face and upper extremity.

Key learning point: A right ACA stroke typically presents with contralateral leg weakness and sensory loss, while a right MCA stroke affects the face and arm more than the leg.

questions.text: You are seeing a 76-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease who is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset right-sided weakness. Her pulse is 83/min and blood pressure is 156/90 mm Hg. Neurological examination reveals right-sided lower facial droop and complete paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities. Tongue position is normal and she is able to swallow liquids without difficulty. Sensation to vibration, pain, position, and light touch is normal bilaterally. She is oriented to person, place, and time, and her speech is normal. Occlusion of which one of the following vessels is the most likely cause of her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A pure motor stroke is caused by infarction in the posterior limb of the internal capsule, which contains the corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers that innervate the motor nuclei on the contralateral side. Therefore, a lesion at this site can cause contralateral hemiplegia as well as weakness in the lower half of the face because the region of the facial nerve nucleus that supplies the lower half of the face only receives unilateral corticobulbar innervation. Other cranial nerve nuclei as well as the region of the facial nerve nucleus that innervates the forehead receive bilateral corticobulbar innervation and are therefore spared. The most common cause of stroke in this region is a lacunar stroke of the lenticulostriate artery (a branch of the middle cerebral artery).

Since the internal capsule also contains somatosensory fibers, some patients with lacunar stroke in the internal capsule may present with sensory loss in addition to hemiparesis. This form of lacunar stroke is referred to as sensorimotor stroke and may be confused with middle cerebral artery stroke.

Key learning point: A pure motor stroke with contralateral hemiplegia and lower facial weakness is most commonly caused by lacunar infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule due to occlusion of the contralateral lenticulostriate arteries.
Image Description:

Fibers of the pyramidal tract originate from the primary motor cortex and descend to the brain stem via the internal capsule. Bulbar corticonuclear fibers extend to each of the cranial nerve nuclei, which innervate the facial muscles. The remaining fibers descend from the brainstem as two divisions of the corticospinal tract. Approximately 80% of these fibers decussate at the level of the medulla (pyramidal decussation) to the contralateral side to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They then descend into the spinal cord to innervate the limbs and digits. The remaining approximately 20% of fibers descend from the brainstem ipsilaterally, forming the anterior corticospinal tract. These decussate at the spinal level of the trunk muscles they innervate.

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would cause motor deficits. However, the motor deficit would predominantly affect the lower extremity and sensory deficits in the lower extremity would also be expected. The upper extremity is usually spared or only mildly affected and the face would be spared. Moreover, an ipsilateral (right) ACA infarct would produce deficits on the contralateral (left) side.

C) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome), which is characterized by ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ipsilateral cerebellar signs (e.g., hemiataxia), impaired pain and temperature sensation in the contralateral body and ipsilateral face, and features of ipsilateral cranial nerve IX, X, and XI palsy (e.g., dysphagia, dysphonia). This patient with pure motor deficits in one half of the body would not have Wallenberg syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior spinal artery (ASA) and vertebral artery supply the medial regions of the lower medulla. Occlusion of the ASA at the level of the brainstem can therefore damage the corticospinal tract and cause motor deficits. However, facial palsy would not be expected since this facial nerve nucleus arises in the lateral region of the upper medulla. Moreover, patients would also have impaired pain and proprioception (due to damage to the medial lemniscus) and features of hypoglossal nerve palsy (e.g., inability to protrude the tongue, tongue deviation).

E) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) causes contralateral motor deficits similar to the ones seen in this patient. However, occlusion of the entire MCA would cause additional symptoms, such as sensory changes, gaze deviation, and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere). In this patient, only a branch of the MCA is affected.
questions.hint: This patient has features of a pure motor stroke without any sensory deficits or cortical signs (e.g., aphasia, agnosia, apraxia). The lesion is most likely located in the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

questions.text: You are seeing a 58-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department with sudden-onset numbness on the right side of his body for the past hour. He has a 15-year history of hypertension managed with hydrochlorothiazide. He is right-handed. On examination, he is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Neurological examination reveals decreased sensation to light pinprick and temperature on the right side of his face and body. Motor strength is 5/5 and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Perfusion of which one of the following brain structures is most likely impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A pure sensory stroke is caused by diminished perfusion of the ventral posterolateral nucleus and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus, which relays sensory information of proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals generally present with unilateral sensory deficits of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus). Chronic hypertension and the resulting lipohyalinosis of small vessels are major risk factors for lacunar infarctions including thalamic strokes.

Key learning point: A pure sensory stroke is most commonly caused by lacunar infarction of the ventral posterior thalamus, resulting in contralateral sensory loss without motor deficits.

B) INCORRECT:

Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of one of its blood-supplying vessels, predominantly the anterior cerebral artery (ACA), and middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of the ACA or MCA may result in numbness. However, a stroke typically on the nondominant (usually right) side would manifest with symptoms of contralateral (left-sided) neglect, while infarction of the dominant (usually left) side would manifest with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Diminished perfusion of the lateral medulla occurs due to occlusion of either the posterior inferior cerebellar artery or branches of the vertebral artery. Infarction of the lateral medulla causes Wallenberg syndrome, which manifests with numbness of the leg and arm contralateral to the lesion. However, patients would also have vestibulocerebellar symptoms, bulbar muscle weakness, and facial paresthesias ipsilateral to the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoperfusion of the subthalamic nucleus leads to contralateral hemiballismus, not sensory deficits.

E) INCORRECT:

Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule occurs due to hemorrhage or occlusion of the lenticulostriate arteries, which supply blood to the greater part of the internal capsule. As fibers of the corticospinal tract pass downward through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, infarction of the posterior limb usually leads to a pure motor stroke with hemiparesis of the leg, arm, and face contralateral to the site of the lesion. Rarely, ischemia of the posterior limb of the internal capsule manifests with isolated contralateral sensory loss, but this is not the most likely etiology of this patient's pure sensory stroke.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (right-sided hemisensory loss) and risk factor for atherosclerosis (hypertension) suggest that he has a pure sensory stroke.

questions.text: You are seeing a 73-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after sudden onset of right-sided weakness. His wife reports that he does not seem to understand simple questions. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. He speaks fluently, but answers questions with nonsensical phrases and is unable to repeat single words. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Global aphasia is a neurologic insult that involves nonfluent aphasia and impaired comprehension. Global aphasia is usually caused by a large lesion affecting the Broca area, the Wernicke area, and the arcuate fasciculus. This patient has impaired comprehension and repetition but speaks fluently.

B) INCORRECT:

Conduction aphasia is usually caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus. This type of aphasia is characterized by impaired repetition with fluent speech and intact comprehension. This patient has poor repetition with fluent speech but impaired comprehension.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterized by impaired comprehension with intact repetition and fluent speech. This patient has fluent speech with impaired comprehension, but his repetition is poor.

D) CORRECT:

Wernicke aphasia is caused by lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, usually along the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) distribution. Patients with Wernicke aphasia typically present with impaired repetition and language comprehension; although they can speak fluently, they produce nonsensical phrases. Furthermore, these patients lack awareness of their impairment, as is the case here. In addition to Wernicke aphasia, signs of an MCA stroke include gaze deviation towards the side of the infarction and contralateral homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing.

See “Types of aphasia” table.

Key learning point: Wernicke aphasia presents with fluent but nonsensical speech, impaired comprehension, poor repetition, and lack of awareness of language deficits due to a lesion in the dominant superior temporal gyrus.
Image Description:

The different types of aphasia can be divided by the presence of good or poor comprehension (red versus blue), good or poor repetition (top three versus bottom three), as well as nonfluent or fluent (light grey versus dark grey).

E) INCORRECT:

Broca aphasia is caused by lesions in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere (e.g., due to an infarct in the superior division of the middle cerebral artery). In patients with Broca aphasia, language production is greatly affected, resulting in nonfluent, telegraphic, and grammatically incorrect speech, whereas this patient speaks fluently. Patients with Broca aphasia are aware of their impaired speech and can become frustrated during the physical examination, but this patient is unaware of his language deficits. Inability to repeat single words and impaired language comprehension are not typically seen in Broca aphasia.
questions.hint: Sudden onset of right-sided body weakness in conjunction with meaningless speech and impaired comprehension should raise concern for a cerebral lesion located in the posterior part of the left superior temporal gyrus (i.e., occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery).

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness over the past 6 months. His medical history includes peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He has a 50-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On auscultation, you detect a bruit on the right side of his neck. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is typically the first-line imaging modality for patients with symptomatic CAS (e.g., TIA, amaurosis fugax, ischemic stroke). Some guidelines also recommend ultrasonography of the neck to screen for CAS in asymptomatic patients with a carotid bruit and multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In patients with CAS, ultrasonography shows a focally-increased velocity of blood flow. Duplex ultrasonography is an inexpensive, noninvasive test with high specificity and sensitivity for the detection of CAS. It can also quantify the degree of stenosis.

Antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, blood pressure control, and lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation, weight control, regular exercise) are the mainstays of treatment in CAS. Carotid revascularization (typically with carotid endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease and severe stenosis (≥ 70%).

Key learning point: Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is the first-line, noninvasive diagnostic test for evaluating suspected carotid artery stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients with CAS, anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are not used for stroke prevention. Instead, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) are used. Warfarin is used for stroke prevention only in patients with certain risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves).

C) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography of the neck, which requires arterial catheterization, used to be the preferred test for evaluating CAS but it has been replaced by other modalities because it is an invasive and costly procedure that carries a ∼ 4% risk of iatrogenic neurological complications (e.g., stroke). Although it may have some utility in select patient groups (e.g., if the initial imaging modalities reveal discordant results or additional anatomic detail is needed), it would not be used as a first-line diagnostic test.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to identify cardiogenic sources of emboli in patients with symptomatic ischemic neurological disease (e.g., TIA) without a clear intracranial or extracranial vascular etiology. However, this patient's physical exam revealed a carotid bruit that is likely secondary to CAS. Echocardiography would not be the next best step for evaluating CAS.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography and MR angiography are not first-line imaging modalities in the workup of CAS, but they can be used to confirm the diagnosis if the first-line modality shows findings consistent with the condition or yields inconclusive results (e.g., due to significant carotid artery calcification). Angiography also plays a role in preoperative risk stratification and intervention planning.
questions.hint: This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 78-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset difficulty speaking that began one hour ago. His medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. His current medications are pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C, pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. He speaks in short, simple sentences and has difficulty repeating sequences of words, but he can follow simple instructions. On examination, he has a right facial droop, muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Rupture of left posterior cerebral artery malformation.
Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries.
Dissection of the left vertebral artery.
Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery.
Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage into the left posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a left posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause right-sided hemiparesis, as seen in this patient. However, rupture of this artery would also cause right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present here. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries that supply the left posterior limb of the internal capsule can result in right-sided weakness, as seen in this patient. However, Broca aphasia localizes to the inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

C) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the left vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.

D) CORRECT:

Broca aphasia is caused by damage of the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (typically left) hemisphere. This patient additionally has right facial droop, right-sided muscle weakness, and right-sided pronator drift downwards, suggesting an upper motor neuron lesion in the left motor cortex. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the inferior frontal gyrus, as well as the motor cortex. This patient has several risk factors for arteriosclerosis and, therefore, ischemic stroke (hypertension, age > 65 years, diabetes mellitus), making occlusion of the left MCA the most likely cause of his focal neurologic deficits.

Ischemic strokes do not typically cause headaches, whereas hemorrhagic strokes usually manifest with severe headaches.

Key learning point: Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery causes contralateral motor deficits and Broca aphasia due to infarction of the dominant inferior frontal gyrus and adjacent motor cortex.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

E) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which manifests with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits that are consistent with stroke. Telegraphic speech (as evidenced by the use of short, simple sentences), intact comprehension (as evidenced by the ability to follow commands), and impaired repetition of word sequences are consistent with Broca aphasia. The presence of this type of language deficit helps localize the damage to a specific region of the cortex.

questions.text: You are seeing a 78-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after sudden onset of speech difficulties and right-sided arm and leg weakness. On examination, he has paralysis and decreased sensation on the right side, a positive Babinski sign on the right, and slurred speech. CT scan of the head shows a hyperdensity in the left middle cerebral artery with no evidence of intracranial bleeding. After pharmacotherapy is initiated, his symptoms improve rapidly and his weakness completely resolves. Which one of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist used for the prophylaxis of ischemic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, and as treatment for patients with venous thromboembolism. It inhibits hepatic epoxide reductase, thereby blocking synthesis (recycling) of the active, reduced form of vit. K. Without reduced vit. K, γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues cannot occur, which reduces the production of active coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as anticoagulatory proteins C and S. Because this drug takes days to exert and remove its clinically significant anticoagulatory effect, it is primarily used for chronic anticoagulation and has no use in the acute setting.

B) INCORRECT:

Rivaroxaban, a direct factor Xa inhibitor, is used for the prevention of ischemic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and the treatment of venous thromboembolism, to name a few indications. Despite its prophylactic value, it has no role in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke. Hence, it is unlikely to be given to this patient with an acute ischemic stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Heparin is used for the acute treatment of several conditions such as venous thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism, and STEMI. It activates antithrombin III in a manner that inhibits both thrombin and factor X. However, current evidence does not support any short- or long-term benefit from the early use of anticoagulants (e.g., heparin) in acute ischemic stroke. Instead, early anticoagulant use is associated with an increased risk of symptomatic intracranial and extracranial hemorrhage.

D) CORRECT:

Alteplase, a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, is the mainstay of treatment to salvage ischemic tissue in acute ischemic stroke. This drug converts plasminogen to plasmin, which dissolves clots by degrading fibrin. Alteplase is typically administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset but can be used later under specialist guidance. Important contradictions include acute intracranial hemorrhage, recent surgery, severe uncontrolled hypertension, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy.

Key learning point: Alteplase, a tissue plasminogen activator, is the first-line thrombolytic therapy for acute ischemic stroke when given within 4.5 hours of symptom onset and no contraindications are present.

E) INCORRECT:

Prasugrel, a platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor, is given to patients with acute coronary syndrome and for those undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (to prevent coronary stent thrombosis). The drug inhibits platelet aggregation by preventing the expression of Gp IIb/IIIa receptors on the platelet surface. Prasugrel is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or TIA because of the increased risk of significant or fatal bleeding.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms in combination with the CT results (hyperdense occluded vessel) indicate an ischemic stroke caused by an obstructive lesion in the left middle cerebral artery. The drug administered can also be used to treat patients with early myocardial infarctions or unstable patients with a pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with acute onset confusion and right-sided weakness. Physical examination shows weakness and sensory loss more pronounced in the upper extremity and lower face than in the lower extremity. Her eyes deviate to the left, and she has a right homonymous hemianopia. Speech is nongrammatical. What is the most appropriate next step in emergency management?

choices.text: Obtain CT angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is valuable for identifying vascular abnormalities and planning intervention. However, noncontrast head CT should be performed first to distinguish between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous thrombolysis requires exclusion of hemorrhage before administration. While this patient's clinical presentation suggests middle cerebral artery territory ischemic stroke, hemorrhagic stroke can manifest with identical symptoms and must be ruled out with imaging first.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Noncontrast head CT is the initial imaging study of choice for acute stroke evaluation. Noncontrast head CT rapidly distinguishes between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke, which is essential because their treatments are fundamentally different. This patient's clinical findings suggest middle cerebral artery territory involvement, but the cause must be determined before treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy is inappropriate as initial management without first distinguishing stroke type. In hemorrhagic stroke, antiplatelet agents could worsen bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Mechanical thrombectomy consultation may be appropriate for large vessel occlusion. However, this intervention first requires confirmation of ischemic stroke and exclusion of hemorrhage through imaging.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS for sudden onset of left-sided weakness that began 1 hour ago. Past medical history includes hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Vital signs are BP, 168/92; P, 110 and irregular; R, 18; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). On physical examination, he has left facial droop, left arm and leg weakness, and profound left-sided neglect. Non-contrast CT of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intracerebral hemorrhage can cause acute focal neurologic deficits, but CT typically shows a hyperdense parenchymal collection rather than a hyperdense vessel.

B) INCORRECT:

Subarachnoid hemorrhage usually manifests with sudden, severe headache and possible loss of consciousness. CT in SAH shows hyperdensity in the basal cisterns or sulci, not a hyperdense MCA.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis may cause focal deficits, but CT classically shows hyperdensity in venous sinuses such as the superior sagittal sinus, not the MCA.

D) INCORRECT:

Brain tumors more commonly manifest with progressive, not sudden, focal deficits. CT typically shows a hypodense or mixed lesion with surrounding edema and mass effect, not a hyperdense arterial thrombus.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The hyperdense MCA sign is an early CT marker of acute thromboembolic occlusion. The patient’s presentation with contralateral weakness, facial droop, and hemispatial neglect is characteristic of a right MCA infarct.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness and dysarthria that began 90 minutes ago. Vital signs are BP, 200/110; P, 110 (irregular); R, 22; oxygen saturation, 89% on room air. She is confused and coughs frequently. Physical examination shows pooled secretions in her oropharynx and flaccid paralysis of her right side. Noncontrast head CT shows no acute hemorrhage. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI can provide additional diagnostic information but should not delay immediate stabilization measures. A noncontrast head CT has already ruled out hemorrhage.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient is within the time window for thrombolytic therapy and has no hemorrhage on CT. However, stabilization must be achieved before initiating reperfusion therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The patient is unable to protect her airway as evidenced by pooled secretions in the oropharynx, frequent coughing, and hypoxia. Primary survey principles require securing the airway and ensuring adequate oxygenation before proceeding with other stroke-specific interventions.

D) INCORRECT:

While antiplatelet therapy is part of ischemic stroke management, another step in management is more urgently required.

E) INCORRECT:

While this patient's blood pressure must be lowered before thrombolytic therapy, another step in management is more urgently required.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of episodes characterized by involuntary jerking of his right thumb that spreads to his entire right arm and then to the entire right side of the body. Each episode lasts for about 30 seconds and is followed by weakness in his right hand for a few minutes. Over the past 2 weeks, one of these episodes progressed to involve rhythmic jerking of all four extremities and loss of consciousness for approximately 2 minutes. He does not have headaches, visual changes, or a history of recent head trauma. Medical history is remarkable for poorly controlled hypertension and a stroke 5 years ago, which resulted in residual left-sided weakness. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol occasionally. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/108 mm Hg. There is a bruit on the left side of the neck. Neurological examination shows decreased muscle strength in the left upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnostic evaluation?

choices.text: CT angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) is used to evaluate for vascular abnormalities such as aneurysms, arteriovenous malformation, and acute stroke. While vascular lesions can cause seizures, CTA is not the initial test for new-onset focal seizures unless an acute cerebrovascular event is suspected. This patient’s symptoms and history are more consistent with a chronic structural lesion than an acute vascular abnormality.

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid duplex ultrasonography is used to assess extracranial carotid artery stenosis, which this patient likely has. However, this imaging modality cannot detect intracranial structural lesions that may be causing this patient's seizures. While carotid ultrasonography may be appropriate later to evaluate stroke risk, it is not indicated as part of the initial evaluation for seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Continuous electroencephalography (EEG) is useful for detecting ongoing and subclinical seizure activity or for classifying seizure types after imaging. While EEG can localize epileptiform activity, it cannot reliably identify structural lesions such as tumors and post-stroke gliosis. In a patient with new focal seizures and risk factors for intracranial pathology, a different diagnostic modality is more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

MRI of the brain is the best initial diagnostic modality for new-onset focal seizures. In adults, new-onset seizures are most commonly caused by an underlying structural brain abnormality. A history of stroke is a significant risk factor for focal motor seizures with a Jacksonian march pattern, especially in younger patients and/or when the stroke involves the cerebral cortex. MRI is highly sensitive for detecting structural lesions (e.g., tumors, cortical dysplasia, post-stroke gliosis). In adults with new focal seizures, imaging is prioritized over electroencephalography to rule out treatable structural causes.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) is recommended for suspected CNS infection (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis) and in the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). A CNS infection typically manifests with fever, headache, altered mental status, or meningeal signs, while patients with SAH typically present with a thunderclap headache that rapidly progresses to nausea, vomiting, and cardiovascular dysfunction. Lumbar puncture is not indicated for new-onset focal seizures without evidence of infection or hemorrhage.
questions.hint: The sequential, progressive spread of motor seizure activity across contiguous body regions, typically beginning in one area (e.g., the fingers) and extending to adjacent regions, is consistent with a Jacksonian march.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after the sudden onset of confusion and right-sided weakness one hour ago. His wife noted his speech became slurred and he was unable to lift his right arm. His medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, for which he is often nonadherent to his medications. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. His blood pressure is 188/102 mm Hg. Physical examination shows expressive aphasia, a right facial droop, and 2/5 strength in the right upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most significant predisposing risk factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperlipidemia, particularly elevated LDL cholesterol, is a key contributor to the development of atherosclerosis, the underlying pathology of thrombotic strokes. Management with statins is a cornerstone of primary and secondary stroke prevention.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus is an important risk factor for ischemic stroke, as it accelerates the process of atherosclerosis and damages small blood vessels. While it approximately doubles the risk of stroke, another risk factor has an even greater impact.

C) CORRECT:

Hypertension is the single most significant modifiable risk factor for both ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke. Chronic, uncontrolled hypertension accelerates atherosclerosis in large vessels (e.g., carotid, middle cerebral arteries) and causes lipohyalinosis in small penetrating arteries, leading to lacunar infarcts. It also weakens vessel walls, increasing the risk of rupture. Effective blood pressure control can reduce the relative risk of a first stroke by 30–40%.

D) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation is a major risk factor for cardioembolic stroke due to thrombus formation in the left atrial appendage. This patient's nonadherence to medication, likely an anticoagulant, further increases this risk. However, a different risk factor is considered the most significant risk factor for stroke overall due to its higher prevalence in the population and its contribution to multiple stroke subtypes, not just cardioembolic events.

E) INCORRECT:

Tobacco use is a potent, dose-dependent risk factor for ischemic stroke. It promotes endothelial dysfunction, a prothrombotic state, and accelerates atherosclerosis. Smoking approximately doubles the risk of ischemic stroke. While it is a major modifiable risk factor, its overall impact is considered less than that of the most important risk factor.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of sudden-onset confusion, right-sided weakness, and slurred speech is consistent with an acute ischemic stroke.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after he suddenly developed difficulty speaking and weakness on his right side approximately one hour ago. His medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation, for which he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), his pulse is 98/min and irregular, and his blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg. Physical examination shows expressive aphasia and a right lower facial droop. Motor strength is 2/5 in the right upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study to guide immediate management?

choices.text: CT angiography of the head and neck
MRI of the brain with diffusion-weighted imaging
Magnetic resonance angiography of the head and neck
Non-contrast CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) is a valuable tool in the acute stroke workup for identifying large vessel occlusions that may be amenable to mechanical thrombectomy. However, it is performed after the preferred initial imaging modality. Another type of imaging must be done first to rule out intracranial hemorrhage before administering intravenous contrast for the CTA, making it a secondary, not initial, diagnostic step.

B) INCORRECT:

Although MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging is the most sensitive test for detecting and confirming an acute ischemic stroke, it is not the preferred initial study in the emergency setting. MRI takes significantly longer to acquire and is less available than the preferred imaging modality. The delay in obtaining an MRI could compromise the narrow time window for administering thrombolytic therapy, in which the priority is the rapid exclusion of hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography visualizes the vasculature of the head and neck and can identify stenosis or occlusion. However, it is not the appropriate initial study because of its longer acquisition time and limited availability. Its role is in the subsequent, non-emergency workup to determine the stroke's cause rather than guiding immediate reperfusion therapy.

D) CORRECT:

A non-contrast CT scan of the head is the most appropriate initial imaging study for all patients with suspected acute stroke because it is rapid, widely available, and highly sensitive for detecting acute intracranial hemorrhage. Ruling out hemorrhage is essential before considering time-sensitive interventions such as intravenous thrombolysis (e.g., alteplase). Although a non-contrast CT may be normal in the early hours of an ischemic stroke, its primary role in the emergency setting is to exclude hemorrhage to safely guide immediate reperfusion therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Carotid duplex ultrasonography is used to assess for carotid artery stenosis, a potential cause of ischemic stroke. Although this is an important part of the subsequent workup to determine the cause and guide secondary prevention strategies, it has no role in the immediate management of an acute stroke. This study does not provide information about the intracranial pathology (ischemia vs. hemorrhage) needed for urgent treatment decisions.
questions.hint: This patient presents with typical features of an acute stroke. The most critical initial step is to differentiate between an ischemic and a hemorrhagic stroke, as their treatments are contraindicated for one another.

questions.text: A 78-year-old left-handed woman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency room because of sudden-onset right leg weakness and urinary incontinence. Neurologic examination shows decreased sensation over the right thigh. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the right lower extremity and 4/5 in the right upper extremity. Strength and sensation in the face are normal but she has difficulty initiating sentences and she is unable to write her name. The most likely cause of this patient’s condition is an occlusion of which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior cerebral artery (ACA) strokes typically manifest with contralateral sensorimotor deficits, language deficits, and urinary incontinence. This woman's sensorimotor deficits are ipsilateral to the right ACA territory, which is inconsistent with a right ACA stroke.

B) INCORRECT:

Vertebrobasilar artery strokes can manifest with vertigo, tinnitus, visual deficits, gait ataxia, and ipsilateral cranial nerve deficits with contralateral paresthesias and hemiplegia. Rarely, it can cause locked-in syndrome. Although this patient presents with sensorimotor deficits, there is no evidence of cranial nerve or cerebellar involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) strokes typically manifest with visual field defects, contralateral hemisensory loss, and vertigo. Right-sided PCA strokes may also cause visual recognition deficits (prosopagnosia). Although this patient does have sensory deficits, a PCA occlusion would not explain her hemiparesis, incontinence, or aphasia. Her sensory deficits are also right-sided, as opposed to the left-sided symptoms expected in a right PCA stroke.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

D) INCORRECT:

Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) strokes typically manifest with visual field defects, contralateral hemisensory loss, and vertigo. Left-sided PCA strokes can also cause language deficits (alexia, anomic aphasia). Although this patient has right-sided sensory deficits, a PCA occlusion would not explain her hemiparesis or incontinence. She also lacks the visual deficits and vertigo typically seen in PCA strokes.

E) INCORRECT:

Middle cerebral artery (MCA) strokes typically manifest with contralateral sensorimotor deficits (face and upper extremities more pronounced than lower extremities), gaze deviation, aphasia (or hemineglect), and contralateral homonymous hemianopia. Although this patient has right-sided sensorimotor deficits and aphasia, the pattern of weakness (i.e., legs > arms) is the opposite of what would be expected in MCA stroke.
Image Description:

A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:

– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

F) INCORRECT:

Vertebrobasilar artery strokes can manifest with vertigo, tinnitus, visual deficits, gait ataxia, and ipsilateral cranial nerve deficits with contralateral paresthesias and hemiplegia. Rarely, it can cause locked-in syndrome. Although this patient presents with right sensorimotor deficits, there is no evidence of cranial nerve or cerebellar involvement.

G) INCORRECT:

Middle cerebral artery (MCA) strokes typically manifest with contralateral sensorimotor deficits (face and upper extremities more pronounced than lower extremities), gaze deviation, aphasia (or hemineglect), and contralateral homonymous hemianopia. Although this patient has sensorimotor deficits and aphasia, the pattern of weakness (right legs > right arms) is the opposite of what would be expected in a right MCA stroke.

H) CORRECT:

Anterior cerebral artery (ACA) strokes manifest with contralateral sensorimotor deficits (more pronounced in the lower extremity than in the upper extremity), urinary incontinence, and, less commonly, speech and language deficits (typically transcortical motor aphasia). Limb apraxia and abulia can also be seen. This patient's right-sided sensorimotor deficits, incontinence, and aphasia are consistent with a left ACA stroke.
questions.hint: This patient's lower extremity deficits, urinary incontinence, and transcortical motor aphasia raise concern for a stroke in a specific vascular distribution.
